	Portions of the registrant&#146;s definitive Proxy Statement to be filed within 120 days of the close of IMAX Corporation&#146;s fiscal year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, with the Securities and Exchange Commission pursuant to Regulation&nbsp;14A involving the election of directors and the annual meeting of the stockholders of the registrant (the &#147;Proxy Statement&#148;) are
	incorporated by reference in Part III of this
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Form&nbsp;10-K
</FONT>
	to the extent described therein.
</P>

<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	IMAX CORPORATION
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	EXCHANGE RATE DATA
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Unless otherwise
	indicated, all dollar amounts in this document are expressed in United States (&#147;U.S.&#148;) dollars. The following table sets forth, for the periods indicated, certain exchange rates based on the noon buying rate in the City of New York for
	cable transfers in foreign currencies as certified for customs purposes by the Bank of Canada (the &#147;Noon Buying Rate&#148;). Such rates quoted are the number of U.S.&nbsp;dollars per one Canadian dollar and are the inverse of rates quoted by
	the Bank of Canada for Canadian dollars per U.S.&nbsp;$1.00. The average exchange rate is based on the average of the exchange rates on the last day of each month during such periods. The Noon Buying Rate on December&nbsp;31, 2016 was
	U.S.&nbsp;$0.7448.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	SPECIAL NOTE&nbsp;REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING INFORMATION
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Certain statements included in this annual report may constitute &#147;forward-looking statements&#148; within the meaning of the United States
	Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, references to future capital expenditures (including the amount and nature thereof), business and technology strategies and measures
	to implement strategies, competitive strengths, goals, expansion and growth of business, operations and technology, plans and references to the future success of IMAX Corporation together with its consolidated subsidiaries (the &#147;Company&#148;)
	and expectations regarding the Company&#146;s future operating, financial and technological results. These forward-looking statements are based on certain assumptions and analyses made by the Company in light of its experience and its perception of
	historical trends, current conditions and expected future developments, as well as other factors it believes are appropriate in the circumstances. However, whether actual results and developments will conform with the expectations and predictions of
	the Company is subject to a number of risks and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, risks associated with investments and operations in foreign jurisdictions and any future international expansion, including those related to economic,
	political and regulatory policies of local governments and laws and policies of the United States and Canada; risks related to the Company&#146;s growth and operations in China; the performance of IMAX DMR films; the signing of theater system
	agreements; conditions, changes and developments in the commercial exhibition industry; risks related to currency fluctuations; the potential impact of increased competition in the markets within which the Company operates; competitive actions by
	other companies; the failure to respond to change and advancements in digital technology; the Company&#146;s largest customer accounting for a significant portion of the Company&#146;s revenue and backlog; risks related to new business initiatives;
	conditions in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-home
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	out-of-home
</FONT>
</FONT>
	entertainment industries; the opportunities (or lack thereof) that may be presented to
	and pursued by the Company; risks related to cyber-security; risks related to the Company&#146;s inability to protect the Company&#146;s intellectual property; general economic, market or business conditions; the failure to convert theater system
	backlog into revenue; changes in laws or regulations; and other factors, many of which are beyond the control of the Company. Consequently, all of the forward-looking statements made in this annual report are qualified by these cautionary
	statements, and actual results or anticipated developments by the Company may not be realized, and even if substantially realized, may not have the expected consequences to, or effects on, the Company. The Company undertakes no obligation to update
	publicly or otherwise revise any forward-looking information, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
</P>

</SUP>
	, DMR
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	&reg;
</SUP>
	, IMAX nXos
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	&reg;
</SUP>
	, IMAX think big
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	&reg;
</SUP>
	, think big
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	&reg;
</SUP>
	and IMAX Is Believing
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	&reg;
</SUP>
	, are trademarks and trade names of the Company
	or its subsidiaries that are registered or otherwise protected under laws of various jurisdictions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	3
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage4"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<EFX_PART_I>
<A NAME="FIS_PART_I"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
<A NAME="D339843D10K_HTM_TX339843_1">
</A>
	PART&nbsp;I
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_BUSINESS>
<A NAME="FIS_BUSINESS"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<A NAME="D339843D10K_HTM_TX339843_2">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;1.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Business
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is a Canadian corporation that was formed in
	March 1994 as a result of an amalgamation between WGIM Acquisition Corp. and the former IMAX Corporation (&#147;Predecessor IMAX&#148;). Predecessor IMAX was incorporated in 1967.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	GENERAL
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is one of the
	world&#146;s leading entertainment technology companies, specializing in motion picture technologies and presentations. IMAX offers a unique
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	end-to-end
</FONT>
</FONT>
	cinematic
	solution combining proprietary software, theater architecture and equipment to create the highest-quality, most immersive motion picture experience for which the IMAX&reg; brand has become known globally. Top filmmakers and studios utilize IMAX
	theaters to connect with audiences in innovative ways, and as such, IMAX&#146;s theater network is among the most important and successful theatrical distribution platforms for major event films around the world.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s principal businesses are:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the design and manufacture of premium theater systems (&#147;IMAX theater systems&#148;) and the sale, lease or contribution of those systems to customers under theater system arrangements; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the Digital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Re-Mastering
</FONT>
	of films into the IMAX format and the exhibition of those films in the IMAX theater network.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	IMAX theater systems are based on proprietary and patented technology developed over the course of the Company&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	49-year
</FONT>
	history. The Company&#146;s customers who purchase, lease or otherwise acquire the IMAX theater systems through joint revenue sharing arrangements are theater exhibitors that operate commercial theaters
	(particularly multiplexes), museums, science centers, or destination entertainment sites. The Company generally does not own IMAX theaters, but licenses the use of its trademarks along with the sale, lease or contribution of the IMAX theater system.
	The Company refers to all theaters using the IMAX theater system as &#147;IMAX theaters&#148;.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	IMAX theater systems combine:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	IMAX DMR (Digital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Re-Mastering)
</FONT>
	movie conversion technology, which results in higher image and sound fidelity than conventional cinema experiences;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	advanced, high-resolution projectors with specialized equipment and automated theater control systems, which generate significantly more contrast and brightness than conventional theater systems;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	large screens and proprietary theater geometry, which result in a substantially larger field of view so that the screen extends to the edge of a viewer&#146;s peripheral vision and creates more realistic images;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	sound system components, which deliver more expansive sound imagery and pinpointed origination of sound to any specific spot in an IMAX theater; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	specialized&nbsp;theater acoustics, which result in a four-fold reduction in background noise.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Together these components cause audiences in IMAX theaters to feel as if they are a part of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-screen
</FONT>
	action, creating a more intense, immersive and exciting experience than a traditional theater.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As a result of the immersiveness and superior image and sound quality of
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	, the Company&#146;s exhibitor
	customers typically charge a premium for IMAX DMR films over films exhibited in their other auditoriums.&nbsp;The premium pricing, combined with the higher attendance levels associated with IMAX DMR films, generates incremental
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	for the Company&#146;s exhibitor customers and for the movie studios releasing their films to the IMAX network.&nbsp;The incremental
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	generated by IMAX
	DMR films has helped establish IMAX as a key premium distribution and marketing platform for Hollywood blockbuster films.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company
	believes the IMAX theater network is one of the most extensive premium theater networks in the world with 1,215&nbsp;theater systems (1,123 commercial, 92 institutional) operating in 75&nbsp;countries as at December&nbsp;31, 2016. This compares to
	1,061&nbsp;theater systems (962 commercial, 99 institutional) operating in 67 countries as at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2015. The success of the Company&#146;s digital and joint revenue sharing strategies and the strength of its film slate have enabled
	the Company&#146;s theater network to expand significantly since 2008, upon the introduction of the Company&#146;s xenon-based digital projection system, with the Company&#146;s overall network increasing by 306% and its commercial network
	increasing by 527% since such time. In 2016 and 2015, the Company signed theater agreements for 319 and 138 theater systems, respectively, which are expected to drive additional growth in the Company&#146;s theater network in 2017 and thereafter.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	4
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage5"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company believes that over time its commercial multiplex theater network could grow to
	approximately 2,450 IMAX theaters worldwide from the 1,107 commercial multiplex IMAX theaters in operation as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. While the Company continues to grow in the United States and Canada, it believes that the majority of its future
	growth will come from international markets. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, 63.7% of IMAX theater systems in operation were located within international markets (defined as all countries other than the United States and Canada), up from 58.5% as at
	December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2015, and approximately 87.8% of IMAX theater systems in backlog are scheduled to be installed in international markets, compared to 88.2% as at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2015. Revenues and gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	derived from outside the United States and Canada continue to exceed revenues and gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	from the United States and Canada.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Greater China continues to be the Company&#146;s second-largest and fastest-growing market, measured by revenues.&nbsp;In recent years, the
	Company&#146;s Greater China operations have accounted for an increasingly significant portion of its overall revenues, with approximately 31% of overall revenues generated from the Company&#146;s China operations in 2016. As at December&nbsp;31,
	2016, the Company had 424 theaters operating in Greater China and an additional 334 theaters in backlog that are scheduled to be installed in Greater China by 2022. The Company&#146;s backlog in Greater China represents 67.1% of the Company&#146;s
	current backlog. The Company continues to invest in joint revenue sharing arrangements with select partners to ensure ongoing revenue in this key market.&nbsp;The Company&#146;s largest single international partnership is in China with Wanda Cinema
	Line Corporation (&#147;Wanda&#148;). In 2016, the Company and Wanda signed an agreement for an additional 150 theater systems under a joint revenue sharing arrangement. This increases Wanda&#146;s total commitment to the Company to 360 theater
	systems, of which 345 theater systems are under the parties&#146; joint revenue sharing arrangement. Furthermore, the Company has partnerships with CJ CGV Holdings, Ltd., for a commitment of 120 theater systems (of which 100 theater systems will be
	located in China), and with Guangzhou JinYi Media Corporation for a commitment of 60 theater systems (all of which are located in China).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2014, the Company completed the sale and issuance of 20% of the shares of the Company&#146;s subsidiary, IMAX China Holding, Inc.
	(&#147;IMAX China&#148;), to entities owned and controlled by CMC Capital Partners (&#147;CMC&#148;), an investment fund that is focused on media and entertainment, and FountainVest Partners (&#147;FountainVest&#148;), a China-focused private equity
	firm. The sale price for the interest was $80.0&nbsp;million (collectively, the &#147;IMAX China Investment&#148;). On October&nbsp;8, 2015, IMAX China completed an initial public offering of its ordinary shares on the Main Board of the Hong Kong
	Stock Exchange Limited (the &#147;IMAX China IPO&#148;). Following the IMAX China IPO, the Company continues to indirectly own approximately 68.2% of IMAX China, which remains a consolidated subsidiary of the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company believes that there have been a number of financial, strategic and operating benefits resulting from both the IMAX China
	Investment and the IMAX China IPO. With respect to the IMAX China Investment, the Company believes that the investors&#146; knowledge of, and influence in, the Chinese media and entertainment industry has contributed to the continued expansion of
	IMAX&#146;s theater network in China and the further strengthening of the Company&#146;s government and industry relationships. In addition, the Company believes that the IMAX China IPO provides investors the ability to directly access and evaluate
	the IMAX China business, and provides greater clarity into the business&#146;s performance in the fastest-growing entertainment market in the world.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Over the years, several technological breakthroughs have established IMAX as an important distribution platform for Hollywood&#146;s biggest
	event films. These include:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<U>
	DMR
</U>
	&#151; IMAX&#146;s proprietary DMR technology digitally converts live-action digital films or 35mm to its large-format, while meeting the Company&#146;s high standards of image and sound quality. In a typical
	IMAX DMR film arrangement, the Company receives a percentage, which in recent years has averaged approximately 12.5%, of box-office receipts, net of sales tax, of any commercial films released in the IMAX theater network outside of Greater China
	from the applicable film studio for the conversion of the film to the IMAX DMR format and for access to the Company&#146;s premium distribution platform. Within Greater China, the Company receives a lower percentage of box-office receipts for
	certain films. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had released 294 IMAX DMR films since the introduction of IMAX DMR in 2002. The number of films released on an annual basis that have been converted through the DMR process has increased
	significantly in recent years with the advent of digital technology that has reduced the DMR conversion time and with the strengthening of the Company&#146;s relationships with major Hollywood studios, as well as international studios. Accordingly,
	51 films converted through the IMAX DMR process were released in 2016, as compared to six in 2007.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	5
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage6"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<U>
	IMAX Xenon-Based Digital Projection System
</U>
	&#151; The Company introduced its xenon-based digital projection system in 2008. Prior to 2008, all of IMAX&#146;s large format projectors were film-based and required
	analog film prints. The IMAX xenon-based digital projection system, which operates without the need for such film prints, was designed specifically for use by commercial multiplex operators and allows operators to reduce the capital and operating
	costs required to run an IMAX theater without sacrificing the image and sound quality of
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	. By making
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	more accessible for commercial multiplex operators, the introduction of the IMAX
	xenon-based digital projection system paved the way for a number of important joint revenue sharing arrangements which have allowed the Company to rapidly expand its theater network. Since announcing that the Company was developing xenon-based
	digital projection technology, the vast majority of the Company&#146;s theater system signings have been for xenon-based digital systems. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company has signed agreements for 1,571&nbsp;xenon-based digital systems
	since 2007, 303 of which were signed in 2016 alone. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, 1,093 IMAX xenon-based digital projection systems were in operation, an increase of 16.4% over the 939 xenon-based digital projection systems in operation as at
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 478 IMAX xenon-based digital projection systems were in backlog as compared to 348 xenon-based digital systems in backlog as at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<U>
	IMAX Laser-Based Digital Projection System
</U>
	&#151; As one of the world&#146;s leaders in entertainment technology, the Company strives to remain at the forefront of advancements in cinema technology. To that end,
	the Company introduced its next-generation laser-based digital projection system at the end of 2014, which was
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-developed
</FONT>
	with Barco N.V. and incorporates exclusive technology developed or otherwise obtained
	by the Company. The Company believes that the IMAX laser-based digital projectors present greater brightness and clarity, higher contrast, a wider color gamut and deeper blacks, and consume less power and last longer than existing digital
	technology. The laser projection solution is the first IMAX digital projection system capable of illuminating the largest screens in its network. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, 39 laser-based digital theater systems were operational. The Company is
	in the process of developing a commercial laser-based digital projection system designed for IMAX theaters in multiplexes.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition to the design and manufacture of premium theater systems, the Company is also engaged in the production and distribution of
	original large-format films, the provision of services in support of the IMAX theater network, the provision of post-production services for large-format films, the operation of three IMAX theaters and, from
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	time-to-time
</FONT>
</FONT>
	the conversion of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-dimensional
</FONT>
	(&#147;2D&#148;) and three-dimensional (&#147;3D&#148;) Hollywood feature films for exhibition on IMAX theater systems
	around the world.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	NEW BUSINESS INITIATIVES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is exploring new lines of business, with a focus on location-based experiences, alternative forms of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-cinema
</FONT>
	entertainment and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-home
</FONT>
	entertainment.&nbsp;In the second quarter of 2016, the Company announced its comprehensive virtual reality (&#147;VR&#148;) strategy
	to develop a premium, location-based VR offering that will deliver immersive, multi-dimensional experiences, including entertainment content and games, to branded VR centers (&#147;IMAX VR Centers&#148;). IMAX VR Centers are expected to be located
	in both stand-alone venues as well as multiplexes, malls and other commercial destinations, and will be retrofitted with proprietary VR pods that permit interactive, moveable VR experiences. The Company&#146;s VR initiative is premised on a unique
	combination of premium content, proprietary design and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	best-in-class
</FONT>
</FONT>
	technology.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In order to deliver high quality content to the IMAX VR Centers, the Company has partnered with Google to design and develop a cinema-grade
	IMAX VR camera, which will enable filmmakers and content creators to capture and deliver high-quality,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	360-degree
</FONT>
	content experiences to audiences. In addition, the Company recently announced the creation of
	an approximately $50.0&nbsp;million virtual reality fund (the &#147;VR Fund&#148;) among the Company, its subsidiary IMAX China and other strategic investors. The VR Fund will help finance the creation of an estimated
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	25-30
</FONT>
	interactive VR content experiences over the next three years for use across all VR platforms, including in the IMAX VR Centers. The VR Fund will target premium productions with its Hollywood studio and
	filmmaker partners, as well as gaming publishers and other leading content developers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In January 2017, the Company launched its flagship
	pilot IMAX VR Center in Los Angeles and has signed agreements for additional IMAX VR center pilots in China, the U.S. and the United Kingdom, which are scheduled to open in the coming months. The Company plans to use these pilot locations to test
	several factors including the overall customer experience, pricing models, throughput, types of content featured and differences in geographic areas. If successful, the Company&#146;s intent is to roll out IMAX VR Centers globally.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Through its VR initiative, the Company sees a unique opportunity to combine premium equipment, more robust computing power, and specially
	designed spaces to create a highly differentiated, destination-based VR experience that will draw consumers out of their homes, similar to the strategy it has successfully employed in the cinema space.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	6
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage7"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is also focusing on alternative forms of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-cinema
</FONT>
	entertainment, including original content. In November 2016, the Company announced an agreement with Marvel Television Inc. (&#147;Marvel&#148;) and Disney|ABC Television Group to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-produce
</FONT>
	and exclusively premiere the new ABC series &#147;
<I>
	Marvel&#146;s
</I>
<I>
	Inhumans
</I>
	&#148; in IMAX theaters. Under the agreement, the first two episodes of the series are expected to run worldwide
	exclusively in IMAX theaters for two weeks in September 2017. Several weeks later, the series will premiere on the ABC network in the U.S. and across other networks internationally. As a result of the Company&#146;s significant financing commitment,
	the Company will have an equity participation both in the pilot and in the television series. This agreement marks the first time a live-action television series has debuted in this manner, and the first time the Company has an economic interest in
	a television property.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, the Company announced the creation of the IMAX China Film Fund (the &#147;China Film Fund&#148;) with its
	subsidiary IMAX China, its partner CMC and several other larger investors to help fund Mandarin language commercial films. The China Film Fund, which is expected initially to be capitalized with over $100.0&nbsp;million, will target productions that
	can leverage the Company&#146;s brand, relationships, technology and release windows in China. The China Film Fund is expected to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-finance
</FONT>
	approximately 15 Mandarin-language tent-pole films over three years,
	and will target contributions of between $3.0&nbsp;million and $7.0&nbsp;million per film. The China Film Fund will operate under an IMAX
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	China-CMC
</FONT>
	controlled greenlight committee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Also, in 2014, the Company announced the creation of the IMAX Original Film Fund (the &#147;Film Fund&#148;) to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-finance
</FONT>
	a portfolio of 10 original large format films. The Film Fund, which is intended to be capitalized with up to $50.0&nbsp;million, will finance an ongoing supply of original films that the Company
	believes will be more exciting and compelling than traditional documentaries. The initial investment in the Film Fund was committed to by a third party in the amount of $25.0&nbsp;million, with the possibility of contributing additional funds. The
	Company agreed to contribute $9.0&nbsp;million to the Film Fund over five years starting in 2014 and sees the Film Fund as a self-perpetuating vehicle designed to generate a continuous flow of high-quality documentary content. As at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Film Fund has invested $13.4&nbsp;million toward the development of original films.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has also made
	inroads in the realm of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-home
</FONT>
	entertainment. To that end, the Company has announced home theater initiatives, including a joint venture with TCL Multimedia Technology Holding Limited (&#147;TCL&#148;) to
	design, develop, manufacture and sell a premium home theater system. Since 2013, the joint venture has signed agreements with end users for the sale of more than 140 premium home theater systems, and has signed agreements with distributors for the
	sale of more than 500 home theater systems. Beyond its premium home theater, the Company is also currently developing other components of broader home entertainment platform designed to allow consumers to experience elements of
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	&reg;
</SUP>
	in their homes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	PRODUCT LINES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company believes it is the world&#146;s largest designer and manufacturer of specialty premium projection and sound system components for
	large-format theaters around the world, as well as a significant producer and distributor of large-format films. The Company&#146;s theater systems include specialized IMAX projectors, advanced sound systems and specialty screens. The Company
	derives its revenues from:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	IMAX theater systems (design, manufacture, sale or lease of, and provision of services related to, its theater systems);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Films (production and digital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastering
</FONT>
	of films, the distribution of film products to the IMAX theater network, post-production and print services for films);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Joint revenue sharing arrangements (the provision of its theater system to an exhibitor in exchange for a certain percentage of theater revenue and, in some cases, a small upfront or initial payment);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;

<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Theater system maintenance (the use of maintenance services related to its theater systems); and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Other activities, which include theater operations (owning equipment, operating, managing or participating in the revenues of IMAX theaters), the sale of after-market parts and camera rentals.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Segmented information is provided in note 18 to the accompanying audited consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;8.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	IMAX Theater Systems, Theater System Maintenance and Joint Revenue Sharing Arrangements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s primary products are its theater systems. The Company&#146;s digital projection systems include a projector that offers
	superior image quality and stability and a digital theater control system; a digital audio system delivering up to 12,000 watts of sound; a screen with a proprietary coating technology, and, if applicable, 3D glasses cleaning equipment. IMAX&#146;s
	digital projection system also operates without the need for analog film prints. Traditional IMAX film-based theater systems contain the same components as the digital projection systems but include a rolling loop
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	15/70-format
</FONT>
	projector and require the use of analog film prints. Since its introduction in 2008, the vast majority of the Company&#146;s theater sales have been digital systems. Furthermore, a majority of the
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	7
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage8"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Company&#146;s existing film-based theater systems have been upgraded, at a cost to the exhibitor, to an IMAX digital system. As part of the arrangement to sell or lease its theater systems, the
	Company provides extensive advice on theater planning and design and supervision of installation services. Theater systems are also leased or sold with a license for the use of the world-famous IMAX brand.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s digital projection system provides a premium and differentiated experience to moviegoers that is consistent with what they
	have come to expect from the IMAX brand, while providing for the compelling economics and flexibility that digital technology affords. The relatively low cost of a digital file delivery (approximately $100 per movie per system compared to
	$30&nbsp;thousand per 2D print and $60&nbsp;thousand per 3D print for an IMAX analog film print) ensures programming flexibility, which in turn allows theaters to program significantly more IMAX DMR films per year. More programming increases
	customer choice and potentially increases total
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	revenue. In 2016, 51 films converted through the IMAX DMR process were released to the IMAX theater network as compared to&nbsp;six films in 2007. To
	date, the Company has contracted for the release of 26 DMR titles to its theater network for 2017; however, the Company expects a similar number of films to be released to the network in 2017 as experienced in 2016. The Company remains in active
	discussions with all the major studios regarding future titles for 2017 and beyond. Furthermore, the Company expects to announce both additional local language IMAX DMR films and original and alternative content to be released to the IMAX theater
	network in 2017 and beyond. Supplementing the Company&#146;s film slate of Hollywood DMR titles with appealing local DMR titles is an important component of the Company&#146;s international film strategy.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	To complement its viewing experience, the Company provides digital sound system components which are specifically designed for IMAX theaters.
	These components are among the most advanced in the industry and help to heighten the realistic feeling of an IMAX presentation, thereby providing IMAX theater systems with an important competitive edge over other theater systems. The Company
	believes it is a world leader in the design and manufacture of digital sound system components for applications including traditional movie theaters, auditoriums and IMAX theaters.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The film-based GT and SR systems and the IMAX digital systems are &#147;flat&#148; screens that have a minimum of curvature and tilt and can
	exhibit both 2D and 3D films, while the screen components in dome shaped theaters are 2D only and are popular with the Company&#146;s institutional clients. All IMAX theaters, with the exception of dome configurations, feature a steeply inclined
	floor to provide each audience member with a clear view of the screen. The Company holds patents on the geometrical design of IMAX theaters.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s arrangements for theater system equipment involve a sale, sales-type lease or joint revenue sharing arrangement. As part of
	the purchase, lease or other acquisition of an IMAX theater system, the Company also advises the customer on theater design, supervises the installation of the theater systems and provides projectionists with training in using the equipment. The
	supervision of installation requires that the equipment also be put through a complete functional
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	start-up
</FONT>
	and test procedure to ensure proper operation. Theater owners or operators are responsible for
	providing the theater location, the design and construction of the theater building, the installation of the system components and any other necessary improvements, as well as the theater&#146;s marketing and programming. The Company&#146;s typical
	arrangement also includes trademark license rights whose term tracks the term of the underlying agreement. The theater system equipment components (including the projector, sound system, screen system, and, if applicable, 3D glasses cleaning
	machine), theater design support, supervision of installation, projectionist training and trademark rights are all elements of what the Company considers the system deliverable (the &#147;System Deliverable&#148;). For a separate fee, the Company
	provides ongoing maintenance and extended warranty services for the theater system. The Company&#146;s contracts are generally denominated in U.S.&nbsp;dollars, except in Canada, China, Japan and parts of Europe, where contracts are sometimes
	denominated in local currency.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Sales-type leases typically have an initial
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-year
</FONT>
	term and are
	typically renewable by the customer for one or more additional 5 to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-year
</FONT>
	terms. Under the terms of the typical lease agreement, the title to the theater system equipment (including the projector, the sound
	system and the projection screen) remains with the Company. The Company has the right to remove the equipment for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-payment
</FONT>
	or other defaults by the customer. The contracts are generally not cancelable by
	the customer unless the Company fails to perform its obligations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under a sales agreement, by contrast, the title to the theater system
	equipment components passes to the customer. In certain instances, however, the Company retains title or a security interest in the equipment until the customer has made all payments required under the agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The typical sales-type lease or sales arrangement provides for three major sources of cash flows for the Company: (i)&nbsp;initial fees;
	(ii)&nbsp;ongoing minimum fixed and contingent fees; and (iii)&nbsp;ongoing maintenance and extended warranty fees. Initial fees generally are received over the period of time from the date the arrangement is executed to the date the equipment is
	installed and customer
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	8
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage9"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	acceptance has been received. However, in certain cases, the payments of the initial fee may be scheduled over a period of time after the equipment is installed and customer acceptance has been
	received. Ongoing minimum fixed and contingent fees and ongoing maintenance and extended warranty fees are generally received over the life of the arrangement and are usually adjusted annually based on changes in the local consumer price index. The
	ongoing minimum fixed and contingent fees generally provide for a fee which is the greater of a fixed amount or a certain percentage of the theater
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office.
</FONT>
	The terms of each arrangement vary according to
	the configuration of the theater system provided, the cinema market and the film distribution market relevant to the geographic location of the customer.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company also offers certain commercial clients IMAX theater systems under joint revenue sharing arrangements. The Company has two basic
	types of joint revenue sharing arrangements: traditional and hybrid. Under a traditional joint revenue sharing arrangement, the Company provides the IMAX theater system in return for a portion of the customer&#146;s IMAX
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts and, in some cases, concession revenues, rather than requiring the customer to pay a fixed upfront payment or annual minimum payments. Payments, which are based on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts, are required throughout the term of the arrangement and are due either monthly or quarterly. Certain maintenance and extended warranty services are provided to the customer for a separate
	fixed annual fee. The Company retains title to the theater system equipment components, and the equipment is returned to the Company at the conclusion of the arrangement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under a hybrid joint revenue sharing arrangement, by contrast, the customer is responsible for making upfront payments prior to the delivery
	and installation of the IMAX theater system in an amount that is typically half of what the Company would receive from a straight sale transaction. As with a traditional joint revenue sharing arrangement, the customer also pays the Company a portion
	of the customer&#146;s IMAX
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts over the term of the arrangement, although the percentage of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts owing to the Company is typically half
	that of a traditional joint revenue sharing arrangement. The Company generally retains title to the theater system equipment components, and the equipment is returned to the Company at the conclusion of the arrangement. In limited instances,
	however, title to the theater system equipment components passes to the customer.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under the significant majority of joint revenue sharing
	arrangements (both traditional and hybrid), the initial
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cancellable
</FONT>
	term of IMAX theater systems is 10 years or longer, and is renewable by the customer for one to two additional terms of between three to
	five years. The Company has the right to remove the equipment for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-payment
</FONT>
	or other defaults by the customer. The contracts are
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cancellable
</FONT>
	by the customer unless
	the Company fails to perform its obligations. In rare cases, the contract provides certain performance thresholds that, if not met by either party, allow the other party to terminate the agreement. By offering arrangements in which exhibitors do not
	need to invest the significant initial capital required of a sales-type lease or a sale arrangement, the Company has been able to expand its theater network at a significantly faster pace than it had previously. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the
	Company has entered into joint revenue sharing arrangements for 995&nbsp;systems with 48 partners, 640 of which were in operation as at December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2012, Dalian Wanda Group Co., Ltd. (&#147;Dalian Wanda&#148;), the parent company of Wanda, acquired AMC Entertainment Holdings, Inc.
	(&#147;AMC&#148;). Under common ownership, Wanda and AMC together is the Company&#146;s largest customer, representing approximately 13.5%, 16.0% and 14.5% of the Company&#146;s total revenue in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. In addition, Wanda
	and AMC together represented approximately 40.3% of the commercial network and 39.8% of the Company&#146;s backlog as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. See Risk Factors &#150; &#147;Under common ownership, Wanda and AMC together account for a significant
	and growing portion of the Company&#146;s revenue and backlog. A deterioration in the Company&#146;s relationship with Wanda and/or AMC could materially, adversely affect the Company&#146;s business, financial condition or results of
	operations.&#148; in Item 1A.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	9
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage10"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_3"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Sales Backlog
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s sales backlog is as follows:

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Reflects contractual upfront payments. Future contingent payments are not reflected as these are based on negotiated shares of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	results.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	No fixed upfront or annual minimum payments.&nbsp;Future contingent payments are not reflected as these are based on negotiated shares of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	results.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes 20 laser-based digital theater system configurations, including three upgrades. The Company continues to develop and roll out its laser-based digital projection system. See &#147;Research and Development&#148;
	in this Part I for additional information.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes 24 laser-based digital theater system configurations, including 13 upgrades.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	number of theater systems in the backlog reflects the minimum number of commitments under signed contracts. The dollar value fluctuates depending on the number of new theater system arrangements signed from year to year, which adds to backlog and
	the installation and acceptance of theater systems and the settlement of contracts, both of which reduce backlog. Sales backlog typically represents the fixed contracted revenue under signed theater system sale and lease agreements that the Company
	believes will be recognized as revenue upon installation and acceptance of the associated theater. Sales backlog includes initial fees along with the estimated present value of contractual ongoing fees due over the term, however it excludes amounts
	allocated to maintenance and extended warranty revenues as well as fees in excess of contractual ongoing fees that may be received in the future. The value of sales backlog does not include revenue from theaters in which the Company has an equity
	interest, operating leases, letters of intent or long-term conditional theater commitments. The value of theaters under joint revenue sharing arrangements is excluded from the dollar value of sales backlog, although certain theater systems under
	joint revenue sharing arrangements provide for contracted upfront payments and therefore carry a backlog value based on those payments. The Company believes that the contractual obligations for theater system installations that are listed in sales
	backlog are valid and binding commitments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following chart shows the number of the Company&#146;s theater systems by configuration,
	opened theater network base and backlog as at December 31:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="6" ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1.00PT SOLID #000000">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Backlog includes three upgrades to laser-based digital theater systems from xenon-based digital theater systems
	in existing IMAX theater locations (all institutional).

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

</P>
<A NAME="eolPage11"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes two upgrades from film-based theater systems to xenon-based digital theater systems in existing IMAX theater locations (one commercial and one institutional).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Backlog includes 13 upgrades to laser-based digital theater systems from xenon-based digital theater systems in existing IMAX theater locations (three commercial and 10 institutional).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company estimates that it will install approximately 150&nbsp;-155 new theater systems (excluding upgrades) in 2017. The Company&#146;s
	installation estimates includes scheduled systems from backlog, as well as the Company&#146;s estimate of installations from arrangements that will sign and install in the same calendar year. The Company cautions, however, that theater system
	installations may slip from period to period over the course of the Company&#146;s business, usually for reasons beyond its control.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	IMAX
	theater systems consist of the following configurations:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	IMAX
</I>
<I>
	Digital:
</I>
<I>
	Xenon
</I>
<I>
	Theater
</I>
<I>
	Systems.
</I>
	&nbsp;In
	July&nbsp;2008, the Company introduced a proprietary IMAX xenon-based digital projection system that it believes delivers higher quality imagery compared with other digital systems and that is consistent with the Company&#146;s brand. As at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had installed 1,093&nbsp;xenon-based digital theater systems and has an additional 478&nbsp;xenon-based digital theater systems in its backlog.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	IMAX
</I>
<I>
	Digital:
</I>
<I>
	Laser
</I>
<I>
	Theater
</I>
<I>
	Systems.
</I>
	&nbsp;The Company introduced its next-generation laser-based digital
	projection system at the end of 2014. The Company believes the IMAX laser-based digital projectors present greater brightness and clarity, higher contrast, a wider color gamut and deeper blacks, and consume less power and last longer than existing
	digital technology, capable of illuminating the largest screens in the IMAX theater network. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had installed 39 laser-based digital systems. The Company is in the process of developing a commercial laser-based
	digital projection system designed for IMAX theaters in multiplexes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	IMAX
</I>
<I>
	Flat
</I>
<I>
	Screen
</I>
<I>
	and
</I>
<I>
	IMAX
</I>
<I>
	Dome
</I>
<I>
	Theater
</I>
<I>
	Systems.
</I>
	&nbsp;IMAX flat screen and IMAX dome systems primarily have been installed in institutions such as museums and science centers. Flat screen IMAX theaters were introduced in 1970, while IMAX dome theaters,
	which are designed for tilted dome screens, were introduced in 1973. There have been several significant proprietary and patented enhancements to these systems since their introduction. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were 56 IMAX flat screen
	and IMAX dome theater systems in the IMAX network, as compared to 67 IMAX flat screen and IMAX dome theater systems as at December&nbsp;31, 2015. With the introduction of the IMAX digital theater systems, there has been a decrease in the number of
	IMAX flat screen and IMAX dome theater systems in the network.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	IMAX
</I>
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	GT
</I>
<I>
	and
</I>
<I>
	IMAX
</I>
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	SR
</I>
<I>
	Theater
</I>
<I>
	Systems.
</I>
	&nbsp;IMAX 3D theaters utilize a flat screen 3D system, which produces realistic 3D images on an IMAX screen. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were 27 IMAX 3D GT and IMAX 3D SR theater systems in operation compared
	to 37 IMAX 3D GT and IMAX 3D SR theater systems in operation as at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The decrease in the number of 3D GT and 3D SR theater systems is largely attributable to the conversion of existing 3D GT and 3D SR theater systems to IMAX
	digital theater systems.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Films
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Film Production and Digital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Re-mastering
</FONT>
	(IMAX DMR)
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2002, the Company developed a proprietary technology to digitally
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-master
</FONT>
	Hollywood films into
	IMAX digital cinema package format or
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	15/70-format
</FONT>
	film for exhibition in IMAX theaters at a modest cost that is incurred by the Company. This system, known as IMAX DMR, digitally enhances the image resolution
	of motion picture films for projection on IMAX screens while maintaining or enhancing the visual clarity and sound quality to levels for which
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	is known. This technology has enabled the IMAX theater network to
	release Hollywood films simultaneously with their broader domestic release. The development of this technology was critical in helping the Company execute its strategy of expanding its commercial theater network by establishing IMAX theaters as a
	key, premium distribution platform for Hollywood films. In a typical IMAX DMR film arrangement, the Company receives a percentage, which in recent years has averaged approximately 12.5%, of box-office receipts, net of sales tax, of any commercial
	films released in the IMAX theater network outside of Greater China from the applicable film studio for the conversion of the film to the IMAX DMR format and for access to the Company&#146;s premium distribution platform. Within Greater China, the
	Company receives a lower percentage of box-office receipts for certain films.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other factors beyond the IMAX DMR format, and IMAX&#146;s
	proprietary projection and sound technology, further differentiate IMAX content from other film content. Filmmakers choose IMAX cameras to shoot selected scenes to increase the audience&#146;s immersion in the film and take advantage of the unique
	dimensions of the IMAX screen by shooting the film in a larger aspect ratio. Certain films also enjoy early release windows in IMAX, including
<I>
	Everest:
</I>
<I>
	An
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	and
<I>
	The
</I>
<I>
	Walk:
</I>
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	11
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage12"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	, which were released one week early in IMAX theaters in 2015. Several recent films have featured select sequences shot with IMAX cameras including
<I>
	Captain
</I>
<I>
	America:
</I>
<I>
	Civil
</I>
<I>
	War:
</I>
<I>
	An
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	, released in May 2016;
<I>
	Batman
</I>
<I>
	v
</I>
<I>
	Superman:
</I>
<I>
	Dawn
</I>
<I>
	of
</I>
<I>
	Justice:
</I>
<I>
	An
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	, released in March 2016;
<I>
	Star
</I>
<I>
	Wars:
</I>
<I>
	The
</I>
<I>
	Force
</I>
<I>
	Awakens:
</I>
<I>
	An
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	Experience,
</I>
	released in December 2015;
<I>
	Interstellar:
</I>
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	, released in November 2014; and
<I>
	Transformers
</I>
<I>
	Age
</I>
<I>
	of
</I>
<I>
	Extinction:
</I>
<I>
	An
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	, released in June 2014 among others. In addition, Marvel&#146;s
<I>
	Avengers:
</I>
<I>
	Infinity
</I>
<I>
	War
</I>
<I>
	&#151;
</I>
<I>
	Part
</I>
<I>
	1:
</I>
<I>
	An
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	and
<I>
	Avengers:
</I>
<I>
	Infinity
</I>
<I>
	War
</I>
<I>
	&#151;
</I>
<I>
	Part
</I>
<I>
	2:
</I>
<I>
	An
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	are expected to be shot in their entireties using the IMAX camera, which is the second time a full
	feature length movie will be filmed with the IMAX cameras.
<I>
	Sully:
</I>
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	, released in August 2016, was shot with IMAX cameras for a majority of the film. IMAX theaters therefore serve as an additional distribution
	platform for Hollywood films, just as home video and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pay-per-view
</FONT>
</FONT>
	are ancillary distribution platforms. In some cases, the Company may also have certain distribution
	rights to the films produced using its IMAX DMR technology.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The IMAX DMR process involves the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	in certain instances, scanning, at the highest possible resolution, each individual frame of the movie and converting it into a digital image;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	optimizing the image using proprietary image enhancement tools;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	enhancing the digital image using techniques such as sharpening, color correction, grain and noise removal and the elimination of unsteadiness and removal of unwanted artifacts;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	recording the enhanced digital image onto IMAX
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	15/70-format
</FONT>
	film or IMAX digital cinema package (&#147;DCP&#148;) format; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	specially
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastering
</FONT>
	the sound track to take full advantage of the unique sound system of IMAX theater systems.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The first IMAX DMR film,
<I>
	Apollo
</I>
<I>
	13:
</I>
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience,
</I>
	produced in conjunction with Universal Pictures and
	Imagine Entertainment, was released in September 2002 to 48 IMAX theaters. One of the more recent IMAX DMR films,
<I>
	Fantastic
</I>
<I>
	Beasts
</I>
<I>
	and
</I>
<I>
	Where
</I>
<I>
	to
</I>
<I>
	Find
</I>
<I>
	Them:
</I>
<I>
	An
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	was released in November 2016 to 1,108 IMAX theaters. Since the release of
<I>
	Apollo
</I>
<I>
	13:
</I>
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience,
</I>
	to December&nbsp;31, 2016, an additional 293 IMAX DMR films have been released to the IMAX theater network.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Advances in the IMAX DMR process allow the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastering
</FONT>
	process to meet aggressive film production
	schedules. The Company has decreased the length of time it takes to reformat a film with its IMAX DMR technology.
<I>
	Apollo
</I>
<I>
	13:
</I>
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience,
</I>
	released in September 2002, was
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastered
</FONT>
	in 16&nbsp;weeks, while certain current films can be
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastered
</FONT>
	in less than one week. The IMAX DMR conversion of simultaneous, or
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	&#147;day-and-date&#148;
</FONT>
</FONT>
	releases are done in parallel with the movie&#146;s filming and editing, which is necessary for the simultaneous release of an IMAX DMR film with the
	domestic release to conventional theaters.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The original soundtrack of a film to be released to the IMAX network is
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastered
</FONT>
	for the IMAX six or twelve-channel digital sound systems in connection with the IMAX DMR release. Unlike the soundtracks played in conventional theaters, IMAX
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastered
</FONT>
	soundtracks are uncompressed and full fidelity. IMAX sound systems use proprietary loudspeaker systems and proprietary surround sound configurations that ensure every theater seat is in a good
	listening position.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company believes that the growth in international
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	will
	continue to be an important driver of future growth for the Company. In fact, during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 61.8% of the Company&#146;s gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	from IMAX DMR films was generated in
	international markets. To support growth in international markets, the Company has sought to bolster its international film strategy, supplementing the Company&#146;s film slate of Hollywood DMR titles with appealing local IMAX DMR releases in
	select markets.&nbsp;In 2016, the Company released 12 local language IMAX DMR films, including nine in China, two in Russia and one in Japan, and in 2015, the Company released 11 local language IMAX DMR films, including eight in China and three in
	Japan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, 51 films were converted through the IMAX DMR process and released to theaters in the IMAX network by film studios as
	compared to 44 films in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	12
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage13"></A>

	To date, the Company has announced the following 26 DMR titles to be released in 2017 to the IMAX
	theater network:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>

</I>
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	(Art Pictures Studio, January 2017, Russia only);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	Journey
</I>

	&nbsp;

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
