</EFX_FINANCIAL_DATA>
<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<A NAME="D339843D10K_HTM_TX339843_11">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;7.
</B>
<B>
<I>
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Management&#146;s
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Discussion
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	and
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Analysis
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	of
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Financial
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Condition
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	and
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Results
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	of
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Operations
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	GENERAL
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	IMAX Corporation, together with its consolidated subsidiaries (the &#147;Company&#148;), is one of the world&#146;s leading entertainment
	technology companies, specializing in motion picture technologies and presentations. The Company refers to all theaters using the IMAX theater system as &#147;IMAX theaters&#148;. IMAX offers a unique
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	end-to-end
</FONT>
</FONT>
	cinematic solution combining proprietary software, theater architecture and equipment to create the highest-quality, most immersive motion picture experience for which the IMAX&reg; brand has
	become known globally. Top filmmakers and studios utilize IMAX theaters to connect with audiences in innovative ways, and, as such, IMAX&#146;s network is among the most important and successful theatrical distribution platforms for major event
	films around the world. There were 1,215&nbsp;IMAX theater systems (1,107 commercial multiplexes, 16 commercial destinations, 92 institutional) operating in 75&nbsp;countries as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2016. This compares to 1,061&nbsp;theater
	systems (943 commercial multiplexes, 19 commercial destinations, 99 institutional) operating in 67 countries as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s principal businesses are:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the design and manufacture of premium theater systems (&#147;IMAX theater systems&#148;) and the sale, lease or contribution of those systems to customers under theater system arrangements; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the Digital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Re-Mastering
</FONT>
	of films into the IMAX format and the exhibition of those films in the IMAX theater network.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	IMAX theater systems combine:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	IMAX DMR (Digital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Re-Mastering)
</FONT>
	movie conversion technology, which results in higher image and sound fidelity than conventional cinema experiences;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	advanced, high-resolution projectors with specialized equipment and automated theater control systems, which generate significantly more contrast and brightness than conventional theater systems;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	large screens and proprietary theater geometry, which result in a substantially larger field of view so that the screen extends to the edge of a viewer&#146;s peripheral vision and creates more realistic images;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	sound system components, which deliver more expansive sound imagery and pinpointed origination of sound to any specific spot in an IMAX theater; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	specialized&nbsp;theater acoustics, which result in a four-fold reduction in background noise.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Together these components cause audiences in IMAX theaters to feel as if they are a part of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-screen
</FONT>
	action, creating a more intense, immersive and exciting experience than in a traditional theater.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As a result of the immersiveness and superior image and sound quality of
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience,
</I>
	the Company&#146;s exhibitor
	customers typically charge a premium for IMAX DMR films over films exhibited in their other auditoriums.&nbsp;The premium pricing, combined with the higher attendance levels associated with IMAX DMR films, generates incremental
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	for the Company&#146;s exhibitor customers and for the movie studios releasing their films to the IMAX network.&nbsp;The incremental
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	generated by IMAX
	DMR films has helped establish IMAX as a key premium distribution and marketing platform for Hollywood blockbuster films. Driven by the advent of digital technology that reduced the IMAX DMR conversion time and with the strengthening of the
	Company&#146;s relationships with the major studios, the number of IMAX DMR films released to the theater network per year has increased to 51 films in 2016, up from six films in 2007. The Company expects to release a similar number of IMAX DMR
	films in 2017 as compared to 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As one of the world&#146;s leaders in entertainment technology, the Company strives to remain at the
	forefront of advancements in cinema technology. To that end, the Company introduced its next-generation laser-based digital projection system at the end of 2014, which was
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-developed
</FONT>
	with Barco N.V and
	incorporates exclusive technology developed or otherwise obtained by the Company. The Company believes that the IMAX laser-based projectors present greater brightness and clarity, higher contrast, a wider color gamut and deeper blacks, and consume
	less power and last longer than existing digital technology. The laser projection solution is the first IMAX digital projection system capable of illuminating the largest screens in its network. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, 39 laser-based digital
	systems were operational. The Company is in the process of developing a commercial laser-based digital projection system designed for IMAX theaters in multiplexes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is exploring new lines of business, with a focus on location-based experiences, alternative forms of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-cinema
</FONT>
	entertainment and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-home
</FONT>
	entertainment.&nbsp;In the second quarter of 2016, the Company announced its comprehensive virtual reality (&#147;VR&#148;) strategy to
	develop a premium, location-based VR offering that will deliver immersive, multi-dimensional experiences, including entertainment content and games, to branded VR centers (&#147;IMAX VR Centers&#148;). IMAX VR Centers are expected to be
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	38
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	located in both stand-alone venues as well as multiplexes, malls and other commercial destinations, and will be retrofitted with proprietary VR pods that permit interactive, moveable VR
	experiences. The Company&#146;s VR initiative is premised on a unique combination of premium content, proprietary design and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	best-in-class
</FONT>
</FONT>
	technology.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In order to deliver high quality content to the IMAX VR Centers, the Company has partnered with Google to design and develop a cinema-grade
	IMAX VR camera, which will enable filmmakers and content creators to capture and deliver high-quality,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	360-degree
</FONT>
	content experiences to audiences. In addition, the Company recently announced the creation of
	an approximately $50.0&nbsp;million virtual reality fund (the &#147;VR Fund&#148;) among the Company, its subsidiary IMAX China Holding Inc. (&#147;IMAX China&#148;) and other strategic investors. The VR Fund will help finance the creation of an
	estimated
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	25-30
</FONT>
	interactive VR content experiences over the next three years for use across all VR platforms, including in the IMAX VR Centers. The VR Fund will target premium productions with its Hollywood
	studio and filmmaker partners, as well as gaming publishers and other leading content developers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In January 2017, the Company launched
	its flagship pilot IMAX VR Center in Los Angeles and has signed agreements for additional IMAX VR center pilots in China, the U.S. and the United Kingdom, which are scheduled to open in the coming months. The Company plans to use these pilot
	locations to test several factors including the overall customer experience, pricing models, throughput, types of content featured and differences in geographic areas. If successful, the Company&#146;s intent is to roll out IMAX VR Centers globally.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Through its VR initiative, the Company sees a unique opportunity to combine premium equipment, more robust computing power, and specially
	designed spaces to create a highly differentiated, destination-based VR experience that will draw consumers out of their homes, similar to the strategy it has successfully employed in the cinema space.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is also focusing on alternative forms of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-cinema
</FONT>
	entertainment, including original
	content. In November 2016, the Company announced an agreement with Marvel Television Inc. (&#147;Marvel&#148;) and Disney|ABC Television Group to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-produce
</FONT>
	and exclusively premiere the new ABC series
	&#147;
<I>
	Marvel&#146;s
</I>
<I>
	Inhumans
</I>
	&#148; in IMAX theaters. Under the agreement, the first two episodes of the series are expected to run worldwide exclusively in IMAX theaters for two weeks in September 2017. Several weeks later, the series
	will premiere on the ABC network in the U.S. and across other networks internationally. As a result of the Company&#146;s significant financing commitment, the Company will have an equity participation both in the pilot and in the television series.
	This agreement marks the first time a live-action television series has debuted in this manner, and the first time the Company has an economic interest in a television property.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, the Company announced the creation of the IMAX China Film Fund (the &#147;China Film Fund&#148;) with its subsidiary IMAX China, its
	partner CMC and several other large investors to help fund Mandarin language commercial films. The China Film Fund, which is expected initially to be capitalized with over $100.0&nbsp;million, will target productions that can leverage the
	Company&#146;s brand, relationships, technology and release windows in China. The China Film Fund is expected to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-finance
</FONT>
	approximately 15 Mandarin-language tent-pole films over three years, and will target
	contributions of between $3.0&nbsp;million and $7.0&nbsp;million per film. The China Film Fund will operate under an IMAX
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	China-CMC
</FONT>
	controlled greenlight committee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Also, in 2014, the Company announced the creation of the IMAX Original Film Fund (the &#147;Film Fund&#148;) to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-finance
</FONT>
	a portfolio of 10 original large format films. The Film Fund, which is intended to be capitalized with up to $50.0&nbsp;million, will finance an ongoing supply of original films that the Company
	believes will be more exciting and compelling than traditional documentaries. The initial investment in the Film Fund was committed to by a third party in the amount of $25.0&nbsp;million, with the possibility of contributing additional funds. The
	Company agreed to contribute $9.0&nbsp;million to the Film Fund over five years starting in 2014 and sees the Film Fund as a self-perpetuating vehicle designed to generate a continuous flow of high-quality documentary content. As at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Film Fund has invested $13.4&nbsp;million toward the development of original films.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	With respect to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-home
</FONT>
	entertainment, the Company has announced home theater initiatives, including a joint venture with TCL Multimedia Technology Holding Limited (&#147;TCL&#148;) to design, develop, manufacture and sell a
	premium home theater system. Since 2013, the joint venture has signed agreements with end users for the sale of more than 140 premium home theater systems, and has signed agreements with distributors for the sale of more than 500 home theater
	systems. Beyond its premium home theater, the Company is also currently developing other components of broader home entertainment platform designed to allow consumers to experience elements of
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	&reg;
</SUP>
	in their homes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	39
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage40"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Important factors that the Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer (&#147;CEO&#148;) Richard L.
	Gelfond uses in assessing the Company&#146;s business and prospects include:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the signing, installation and financial performance of theater system arrangements (particularly its joint revenue sharing arrangements and new laser-based projection system);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	film performance and the securing of new film projects (particularly IMAX DMR films);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	revenue and gross margins from the Company&#146;s operating segments;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	earnings from operations as adjusted for unusual items that the Company views as
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-recurring;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the success of new business initiatives (including new content initiatives);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	short- and long-term cash flow projections;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the continuing ability to invest in and improve the Company&#146;s technology to enhance its differentiation of presentation versus other cinematic experiences; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the overall execution, reliability and consumer acceptance of
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The primary revenue sources for the Company can be categorized into two main groups: theater systems and films. On the theater systems side,
	the Company derives revenues from theater exhibitors primarily through either a sale or sales-type lease arrangement or a joint revenue sharing arrangement. Theater exhibitors also pay for associated maintenance and extended warranty services. Film
	revenue is derived primarily from film studios for the provision of film production and digital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastering
</FONT>
	services for exhibition on IMAX theater systems around the world. The Company derives other film
	revenues from the distribution of certain films and the provision of post-production services. The Company also derives a small portion of other revenues from the operation of its own theaters, the provision of aftermarket parts for its system
	components, and camera rentals.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	IMAX Theater Systems: IMAX Systems (Sales and Sales-type Leases), Joint Revenue Sharing Arrangements and Theater
	System Maintenance
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	One of the Company&#146;s principal businesses is the design, manufacture and delivery of premium theater systems
	(&#147;IMAX theater systems&#148;). The theater system equipment components (including the projection system, sound system, screen system and, if applicable, 3D glasses cleaning machine), theater design support, supervision of installation,
	projectionist training and the use of the IMAX brand are all elements of what the Company considers the system deliverable. The IMAX theater systems are based on proprietary and patented technology developed over the course of the Company&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	49-year
</FONT>
	history. The Company provides IMAX theater systems to customers through sales, long-term leases or under joint revenue sharing arrangements. The Company&#146;s customers who purchase, lease or otherwise
	acquire the IMAX theater systems through joint revenue sharing arrangements are theater exhibitors that operate commercial theaters (particularly multiplexes), museums, science centers, or destination entertainment sites. The Company generally does
	not own IMAX theaters, but licenses the use of its trademarks along with the sale, lease or contribution of the IMAX theater system.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	IMAX Systems
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Sales and Sales-Type Lease Arrangements
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company provides IMAX theater systems to customers on a sales or long-term lease basis, typically with an initial
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-year
</FONT>
	term. These agreements typically require the payment of initial fees and ongoing fees (which can include a fixed minimum amount per annum and contingent fees in excess of the minimum payments), as well as
	maintenance and extended warranty fees. The initial fees vary depending on the system configuration and location of the theater. Initial fees are paid to the Company in installments between the time of system signing and the time of system
	installation, which is when the total of these fees, in addition to the present value of future annual minimum payments, are recognized as revenue. Ongoing fees are paid over the term of the contract, commencing after the theater system has been
	installed, and are equal to the greater of a fixed minimum amount per annum or a percentage of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts. Contingent payments in excess of fixed minimum ongoing payments are recognized as revenue
	when reported by theater operators, provided collectibility is reasonably assured. Typically, ongoing fees are indexed to a local consumer price index. Finance income is derived over the term of a financed sale or sales-type lease arrangement as the
	unearned income on that financed sale or sales-type lease is earned. Certain maintenance and extended warranty services are provided to the customer for a separate fixed annual fee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under the Company&#146;s sales agreements, title to the theater system equipment components passes to the customer. In certain instances,
	however, the Company retains title or a security interest in the equipment until the customer has made all payments required under the agreement. Under the terms of a sales-type lease agreement, title to the theater system equipment components
	remains with the Company. The Company has the right to remove the equipment for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-payment
</FONT>
	or other defaults by the customer.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	40
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage41"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The revenue earned from customers under the Company&#146;s theater system sales or lease
	agreements varies from quarter to quarter and year to year based on a number of factors, including the number and mix of theater system configurations sold or leased, the timing of installation of the theater systems, the nature of the arrangement
	and other factors specific to individual contracts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Joint Revenue Sharing Arrangements
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company also provides IMAX theater systems to customers under joint revenue sharing arrangements (&#147;JRSA&#148;). The Company has two
	basic types of joint revenue sharing arrangements: traditional and hybrid.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under a traditional joint revenue sharing arrangement, the
	Company provides the IMAX theater system in return for a portion of the customer&#146;s IMAX
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts and, in some cases, concession revenues, rather than requiring the customer to pay a fixed
	upfront payment or annual minimum payments. Payments, which are based on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts, are required throughout the term of the arrangement and are due either monthly or quarterly. Certain maintenance
	and extended warranty services are provided to the customer for a separate fixed annual fee. The Company retains title to the theater system equipment components, and the equipment is returned to the Company at the conclusion of the arrangement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under a hybrid joint revenue sharing arrangement, by contrast, the customer is responsible for making upfront payments prior to the
	delivery and installation of the IMAX theater system in an amount that is typically half of what the Company would receive from a straight sale transaction. As with a traditional joint revenue sharing arrangement, the customer also pays the Company
	a portion of the customer&#146;s IMAX
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts over the term of the arrangement, although the percentage of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts owing to the Company is
	typically half that of a traditional joint revenue sharing arrangement. The Company generally retains title to the theater system equipment components, and the equipment is returned to the Company at the conclusion of the arrangement. In limited
	instances, however, title to the theater system equipment components passes to the customer.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under the significant majority of joint
	revenue sharing arrangements (both traditional and hybrid), the initial
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cancellable
</FONT>
	term of IMAX theater systems is 10 years or longer, and is renewable by the customer for one to two additional terms of
	between three to five years. The Company has the right to remove the equipment for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-payment
</FONT>
	or other defaults by the customer. The contracts are
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cancellable
</FONT>
	by
	the customer unless the Company fails to perform its obligations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The introduction of joint revenue sharing arrangements has been an
	important factor in the expansion of the Company&#146;s commercial theater network, which has grown by approximately 527% since the beginning of 2008.&nbsp;Joint revenue sharing arrangements allow commercial theater exhibitors to install IMAX
	theater systems without the significant initial capital investment required in a sale or sales-type lease arrangement. Joint revenue sharing arrangements drive recurring cash flows and earnings for the Company, as customers under joint revenue
	sharing arrangements pay the Company a portion of their ongoing
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office.&nbsp;The
</FONT>
	Company funds its joint revenue sharing arrangements through cash flows from operations. As at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2016,
	the Company had 640 theaters in operation under joint revenue sharing arrangements, a 21.0% increase as compared to the 529 joint revenue sharing arrangements open as at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2015. The Company also had contracts in backlog for an
	additional 355 theaters under joint revenue sharing arrangements as at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The revenue earned from customers
	under the Company&#146;s joint revenue sharing arrangements can vary from quarter to quarter and year to year based on a number of factors including film performance, the mix of theater system configurations, the timing of installation of these
	theater systems, the nature of the arrangement, the location, size and management of the theater and other factors specific to individual arrangements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Theater System Maintenance
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For all IMAX
	theaters, theater owners or operators are also responsible for paying the Company an annual maintenance and extended warranty fee. Under these arrangements, the Company provides proactive and emergency maintenance services to every theater in its
	network to ensure that each presentation is up to the highest IMAX quality standard. Annual maintenance fees are paid throughout the duration of the term of the theater agreements and are typically indexed to a local consumer price index.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other Theater Revenues
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company
	derives a small portion of its revenues from other sources. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had two owned and operated IMAX theaters (December 31, 2015 &#151; three owned and operated theaters). In addition, the Company has a commercial
	arrangement with one theater resulting in the sharing of profits and losses and provides management services to three other theaters.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	41
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company also rents its proprietary 2D and 3D large-format film and digital cameras to third party production companies. The Company maintains cameras and other film equipment and also offers
	production advice and technical assistance to both documentary and Hollywood filmmakers. Additionally, the Company generates revenues from the sale of after-market parts and 3D glasses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from theater system arrangements is recognized at a different time from when cash is collected. See &#147;Critical Accounting
	Policies&#148; below for further discussion on the Company&#146;s revenue recognition policies.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Greater China includes China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Macau.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Latin America includes South America, Central America and Mexico.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31,
	2016, 36.3% of IMAX systems in operation were located in the United States and Canada compared to 41.5% as at the end of last year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	To
	minimize the Company&#146;s credit risk, the Company retains title to the underlying theater systems under lease arrangements, performs initial and ongoing credit evaluations of its customers and makes ongoing provisions for its estimates of
	potentially uncollectible amounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company believes that over time its commercial multiplex theater network could grow to
	approximately 2,450 IMAX theaters worldwide from 1,107 commercial multiplex IMAX theaters operating as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. The Company believes that the majority of its future growth will come from international markets. As at
	December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2016, 63.7% of IMAX theater systems in operation were located within international markets (defined as all countries other than the United States and Canada), up from 58.5% as at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2015. Revenues and gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	derived from outside the United States and Canada continue to exceed revenues and gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	from the United States and Canada. Risks associated with
	the Company&#146;s international business are outlined in Risk Factors &#150; &#147;The Company conducts business internationally, which exposes it to uncertainties and risks that could negatively affect its operations, sales and future growth
	prospects&#148; in Item 1A of Part I.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Greater China continues to be the Company&#146;s second-largest and fastest-growing market,
	measured by revenues.&nbsp;The Company&#146;s Greater China operations have accounted for an increasingly significant portion of its overall revenues, with nearly 31% of overall revenues generated from the Company&#146;s China operations in 2016. As
	at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had 424 theaters operating in Greater China with an additional 334 theaters in backlog that are scheduled to be installed in Greater China by 2022. The Company&#146;s backlog in Greater China represents 67.1%
	of the Company&#146;s current backlog. The Company continues to invest in joint revenue sharing arrangements with select partners to ensure ongoing revenue in this key market.&nbsp;The Company&#146;s largest single international partnership is in
	China with Wanda Cinema Line Corporation (&#147;Wanda&#148;). In 2016, the Company and Wanda signed an agreement for an additional 150 theater systems under a joint revenue sharing arrangement. This increases Wanda&#146;s total commitment to the
	Company to 360 theater systems in Greater China, of which 345 theater systems are under the parties&#146; joint revenue sharing arrangement. Furthermore, the Company has a partnership with CJ CGV Holdings, Ltd., for a commitment of 120 theater
	systems, of which 100 theater systems will be located in China. In addition, in 2016, the Company and Guangzhou JinYi Media Corporation
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	42
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage43"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(&#147;JinYi&#148;) expanded its existing commitment to include 40 theater systems under a joint revenue sharing arrangement. With the addition of these theater systems, JinYi&#146;s total
	commitment to the Company is for 60 theater systems, all of which are located in China. See Risk Factors &#150; &#147;The Company faces risks in connection with the continued expansion of its business in China&#148; in Item 1A of Part I.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2014, the Company completed the sale and issuance of 20% of the shares of the Company&#146;s subsidiary, IMAX China Holding, Inc.
	(&#147;IMAX China&#148;), to entities owned and controlled by CMC Capital Partners (&#147;CMC&#148;), an investment fund that is focused on media and entertainment, and FountainVest Partners (&#147;FountainVest&#148;), a China-focused private equity
	firm. The sale price for the interest was $80.0&nbsp;million (collectively, the &#147;IMAX China Investment&#148;). On October&nbsp;8, 2015, IMAX China completed an initial public offering of its ordinary shares on the Main Board of the Hong Kong
	Stock Exchange Limited (the &#147;IMAX China IPO&#148;). Following the IMAX China IPO, the Company continues to indirectly own approximately 68.2% of IMAX China, which remains a consolidated subsidiary of the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table outlines the breakdown of the Commercial Multiplex theater network by arrangement type and geographic location as at
	December 31:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2016, 266 (2015&nbsp;&#150; 261) of the 640 (2015&nbsp;&#150; 529) theaters under
	joint revenue sharing arrangements in operation, or 41.6% (2015 &#150; 49.3%) were located in the United States and Canada, with the remaining 374 (2015&nbsp;&#150; 268) or 58.4% (2015&nbsp;&#150; 50.7%) of arrangements being located in
	international markets. The Company continues to seek to expand its network of theaters under joint revenue sharing arrangements, particularly in select international markets.
</P>

</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Reflects contractual upfront payments. Future contingent payments are not reflected as these are based on negotiated shares of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	results.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	No fixed upfront or annual minimum payments.&nbsp;Future contingent payments are not reflected as these are based on negotiated shares of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	results.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes 20 laser-based digital theater system configurations, including three upgrades. The Company continues to develop and roll out its laser-based digital projection system. See &#147;Research and Development&#148;
	in Item 1 of Part I for additional information.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes 24 laser-based digital theater system configurations, including 13 upgrades.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	number of theater systems in the backlog reflects the minimum number of commitments under signed contracts. The dollar value fluctuates depending on the number of new theater system arrangements signed from year to year, which adds to backlog, and
	the installation and acceptance of theater systems and the settlement of contracts, both of which reduce backlog. Sales backlog typically represents the fixed contracted revenue under signed theater system sale and lease agreements that the Company
	believes will be recognized as revenue upon installation and acceptance of the associated theater. Sales backlog includes initial fees along with the estimated present value of contractual ongoing fees due over the term; however, it excludes amounts
	allocated to maintenance and extended warranty revenues as well as fees in excess of contractual ongoing fees that may be received in the future. The value of sales backlog does not include revenue from theaters in which the Company has an equity
	interest, operating leases, letters of intent or long-term conditional theater commitments. The value of theaters under joint revenue sharing arrangements is excluded from the dollar value of sales backlog, although certain theater systems under
	joint revenue sharing arrangements provide for contracted upfront payments and therefore carry a backlog value based on those payments. The Company believes that the contractual obligations for theater system installations that are listed in sales
	backlog are valid and binding commitments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	From time to time, in the normal course of its business, the Company will have customers who
	are unable to proceed with a theater system installation for a variety of reasons, including the inability to obtain certain consents, approvals or financing. Once the determination is made that the customer will not proceed with installation, the
	agreement with the customer is terminated or amended. If the agreement is terminated, once the Company and the customer are released from all their future obligations under the agreement, all or a portion of the initial rents or fees that the
	customer previously made to the Company are recognized as revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table outlines the breakdown of the total backlog by
	arrangement type and geographic location as at December&nbsp;31:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Approximately 87.8% of IMAX theater system arrangements in backlog as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 are scheduled
	to be installed in international markets (2015 &#150; 88.2%).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	44
</P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes four signings which replaced theaters under an existing arrangement in backlog.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes one used theater system (2015 &#150; one used theater system).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes 14 installations of an upgrade to a laser-based digital system, 12 under sales and sales-type lease arrangements and two under joint revenue sharing arrangements (2015 &#150; 16 laser-based digital systems, ten
	under sales and sales-type lease arrangements, one under a short-term operating lease arrangement and five under joint revenue sharing arrangements).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes two installations of an upgrade to a xenon-based digital system under sales arrangements (2015 &#150; two xenon-based digital systems, one under a sales and sales-type lease arrangement and one under a
	short-term operating lease arrangement).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company estimates that it will install approximately 150&nbsp;-155 new theater
	systems (excluding upgrades) in 2017. The Company&#146;s installation estimates include scheduled systems from backlog, as well as the Company&#146;s estimate of installations from arrangements that will sign and install in the same calendar year.
	The Company cautions, however, that theater system installations may slip from period to period over the course of the Company&#146;s business, usually for reasons beyond its control.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Films: Digital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Re-Mastering
</FONT>
	(IMAX DMR) and other film revenue
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Digital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Re-Mastering
</FONT>
	(IMAX DMR)
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2002, the Company developed a proprietary technology to digitally
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-master
</FONT>
	Hollywood films into
	IMAX digital cinema package format or
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	15/70-format
</FONT>
	film for exhibition in IMAX theaters at a modest cost that is incurred by the Company. This system, known as IMAX DMR, digitally enhances the image resolution
	of motion picture films for projection on IMAX screens while maintaining or enhancing the visual clarity and sound quality to levels for which
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	is known. This technology enabled the IMAX theater network to release
	Hollywood films simultaneously with their broader domestic release. The development of this technology was critical in helping the Company execute its strategy of expanding its commercial theater network by establishing IMAX theaters as a key,
	premium distribution platform for Hollywood films. In a typical IMAX DMR film arrangement, the Company receives a percentage, which in recent years has averaged approximately 12.5%, of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts of
	any commercial films released in the IMAX network from the applicable film studio for the conversion of the film to the IMAX DMR format and for access to the Company&#146;s premium distribution platform.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	IMAX films benefit from enhancements made by individual filmmakers exclusively for the IMAX release, and filmmakers and studios have sought
	IMAX-specific enhancements in recent years to generate interest in and excitement for their films. Such enhancements include shooting selected scenes with IMAX cameras to increase the audience&#146;s immersion in the film and taking
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	45
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage46"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	advantage of the unique dimensions of the IMAX screen by shooting the film in a larger aspect ratio. Certain films also enjoy early release windows in IMAX, including
<I>
	Everest:
</I>
<I>
	An
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	3D
</I>
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	and
<I>
	The
</I>
<I>
	Walk:
</I>
<I>
	The
</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	, which were released one week early in IMAX theaters in 2015. Several recent films have featured select sequences shot with IMAX cameras including
<I>
	Captain
</I>

</I>

	, released in May 2016;

</I>

	are expected to be shot in their entireties using the IMAX camera, which is the
	second time a full feature length movie will be filmed with the IMAX cameras.

</I>
	IMAX
<I>
	Experience
</I>
	, released in August 2016, was shot with IMAX cameras for a majority of the film.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The original soundtrack of a film to be released to the IMAX theater network is
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastered
</FONT>
	for the
	IMAX digital sound systems in connection with the IMAX DMR release. Unlike the soundtracks played in conventional theaters, IMAX
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastered
</FONT>
	soundtracks are uncompressed and full fidelity. IMAX sound systems
	use proprietary loudspeaker systems and proprietary surround sound configurations that ensure every theater seat is in a good listening position.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company believes that the growth in international
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	is an important driver of future
	growth for the Company. During 2016 61.8% of the Company&#146;s gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	from IMAX DMR films was generated in international markets, as compared to 60.8% in 2015. To support growth in international
	markets, the Company continues to bolster its international film strategy, supplementing the Company&#146;s film slate of Hollywood DMR titles with appealing local IMAX DMR releases in select markets.&nbsp;During 2016, the Company released 12 local
	language IMAX DMR films, including nine in China, two in Russia and one in Japan. In 2015, 11 local language IMAX DMR films were released, including eight in China and three in Japan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	To date, the Company has announced the following 26 DMR titles to be released in 2017 to the IMAX theater network:
</P>

<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	worldwide exclusively in IMAX theaters for two weeks in September 2017, and several weeks later, the series will premiere on the ABC network. The Company will have an equity participation both in
	the pilot and in the television series, representing the first time the Company will have an economic interest in a television property.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company remains in active negotiations with all of the major Hollywood studios, as well as international studios, for additional films to
	fill out its short and long-term film slate, and anticipates that the number of IMAX DMR films to be released to the IMAX network in 2017 will be similar to the IMAX DMR films released to the IMAX network in 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other Film Revenues: Film Distribution and Post-Production
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is also a distributor of large-format films, primarily for its institutional theater partners. The Company generally distributes
	films which it produces or for which it has acquired distribution rights from independent producers. The Company receives either a percentage of the theater
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	receipts or a fixed amount as a
	distribution fee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company also provides film post-production and quality control services for large-format films (whether produced
	internally or externally), and digital post-production services.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	CRITICAL ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND ESTIMATES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company prepares its consolidated financial statements in accordance with United States Generally Accepted Accounting Principles
	(&#147;U.S. GAAP&#148;).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The preparation of these consolidated financial statements requires management to make estimates and judgments
	that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses. On an ongoing basis, management evaluates its estimates, including those related to selling prices associated with the individual elements in multiple element
	arrangements; residual values of leased theater systems; economic lives of leased assets; allowances for potential uncollectibility of accounts receivable, financing receivables and net investment in leases; write-downs for inventory obsolescence;
	ultimate revenues for film assets; impairment provisions for film assets, long-lived assets and goodwill; depreciable lives of property, plant and equipment; useful lives of intangible assets; pension plan and post retirement assumptions; accruals
	for contingencies including tax contingencies; valuation allowances for deferred income tax assets; and, estimates of the fair value and expected exercise dates of stock-based payment awards. Management bases its estimates on historical experience,
	future expectations and other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable at the date of the consolidated financial statements. Actual results may differ from these estimates due to uncertainty involved in measuring, at a specific point in time,
	events which are continuous in nature, and differences may be material. The Company&#146;s significant accounting policies are discussed in note&nbsp;2 to its audited consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;8 of the Company&#146;s Annual
	Report for the Fiscal Year ended December 31, 2016 (this &#147;2016
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Form&nbsp;10-K&#148;).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	Company considers the following significant estimates, assumptions and judgments to have the most significant effect on its results:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Revenue
	Recognition
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company generates revenue from various sources as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&#149;
</TD>

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	design, manufacture, sale and lease of proprietary theater systems for IMAX theaters principally owned and operated by commercial and institutional customers located in 75 countries as at December&nbsp;31, 2016;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</TD>

</TD>

</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
