<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Includes&nbsp;21&nbsp;laser-based&nbsp;digital&nbsp;system&nbsp;configurations&nbsp;(seven&nbsp;new&nbsp;laser-based&nbsp;digital&nbsp;systems,&nbsp;
	five&nbsp;under&nbsp;sales&nbsp;arrangements&nbsp;and
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two&nbsp;under&nbsp;joint&nbsp;revenue&nbsp;sharing&nbsp;arrangements&nbsp;and&nbsp;14&nbsp;laser-based&nbsp;digital&nbsp;system&nbsp;upgrades,&nbsp;12&nbsp;under&nbsp;sales&nbsp;arrangements&nbsp;and&nbsp;two
</FONT>
	under&nbsp;joint&nbsp;revenue&nbsp;sharing&nbsp;arrangements).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes 17 laser-based digital system configurations (one new laser-based digital system under sales arrangement and 16 laser-based digital system upgrades, 10 under sales arrangements, one under a short-term operating
	lease arrangement and five under joint revenue sharing arrangements).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	IMAX theater system margin from full, new sales and
	sales-type lease systems was 63.7% in 2016, which was lower than the 65.9% experienced in 2015. On average, the Company experiences lower margins from the installation of laser-based digital systems. The Company expects these margins to improve
	through further development of its commercial laser-based projection system. Gross margin from theater system upgrades was $1.7&nbsp;million in 2016, as compared to $0.8&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily due to the nature of the theater system
	components required for each respective upgrade. In addition, the Company recorded a charge of $0.6&nbsp;million upon the upgrade of xenon-based digital systems under operating lease arrangements to laser-based digital systems under sales or
	sales-type lease arrangements in IMAX Systems margin, as compared to a charge of $0.7&nbsp;million in 2015 for components there were not used in the upgrade and cannot be used for future installations. Furthermore, in 2016 the Company incurred a
	charge of $0.2&nbsp;million, as compared to $0.1&nbsp;million in 2015, due to a reduction in the net realizable value of its inventories. Gross margin varies depending upon the number of theater system commitments with a single respective exhibitor,
	an exhibitor&#146;s location and other various factors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	60
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage61"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenues from sales and sales-type leases includes settlement revenue of $1.3&nbsp;million in
	2016 as compared to $0.1&nbsp;million in 2015. Costs associated with settlements consist primarily of commission costs. Gross margin from sales and sales-type leases include settlement margin of $1.2&nbsp;million in 2016, as compared to
	$0.1&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Ongoing rent revenue and finance income increased to $16.0&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to $15.2&nbsp;million
	in 2015, due to continued growth in the Company&#146;s theater network. Gross margin for ongoing rent and finance income increased to $15.3&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to $14.4&nbsp;million in 2015. Contingent fees included in this caption
	amounted to $4.3&nbsp;million and $3.8&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other revenue increased to $19.4&nbsp;million in 2016
	as compared to $17.6&nbsp;million in 2015. Other revenue primarily includes revenue generated from the Company&#146;s theater operations, camera rental business and after-market sales of projection system parts and 3D glasses. The growth in revenue
	is primarily the result of an increase in revenue from after-market sales of 3D glasses and camera rentals, as compared to the prior year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The gross margin recognized from other revenue decreased to less than $0.1&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared to $0.3&nbsp;million in 2015,
	primarily due to new business initiatives which are in development and/or the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	start-up
</FONT>
	phase, offset by an increase in camera rentals gross margin compared to the prior year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Theater System Maintenance
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Theater system maintenance revenue increased 9.4% to $40.4&nbsp;million in 2016 from $36.9&nbsp;million in 2015. Theater system maintenance
	gross margin increased to $13.7&nbsp;million in 2016 from $12.7&nbsp;million in 2015. The Company recorded a write-down of $0.2&nbsp;million and less than $0.1&nbsp;million for certain service parts inventories in 2016 and 2015, respectively.
	Maintenance revenue continues to grow as the number of theaters in the IMAX theater network grows. Maintenance margins vary depending on the mix of theater system configurations in the theater network, volume-pricing related to larger relationships
	and the timing and the date(s) of installation and/or service.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Joint Revenue Sharing Arrangements
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenues from joint revenue sharing arrangements decreased 7.8% to $91.4&nbsp;million in 2016 from $99.1&nbsp;million in 2015. The Company
	ended the year with 640 theaters operating under joint revenue sharing arrangements, as compared to 529 theaters at the end of 2015, an increase of 21.0%. The decrease in revenues from joint revenue sharing arrangements was due to weaker film
	performance in 2016, partly a result of unfavourable exchange rates between applicable local currencies and the U.S. dollar, partially offset by an increase in the number of theaters under joint revenue sharing arrangements in operation as compared
	to the prior year. During 2016, the Company installed 109 full, new theaters under joint revenue sharing arrangements, as compared to 80 full new theaters during 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The gross margin from joint revenue sharing arrangements was $59.8&nbsp;million in 2016, as compared to $68.4&nbsp;million in 2015. Included
	in the calculation of the 2016 gross margin were certain advertising, marketing and commission costs primarily associated with new theater launches of $4.1&nbsp;million, as compared to $4.3&nbsp;million for such expenses in 2015. The lower gross
	margin experienced in 2016 is primarily a result of the weaker film performance (as discussed above) over the prior year comparative period, as well as higher depreciation expense resulting from continuous growth in the number of operational
	theaters under joint revenue sharing arrangements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Film
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from the Company&#146;s film segments increased to $120.5&nbsp;million in 2016 from $118.0&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily due to an
	increase in film distribution revenue from IMAX original films. Film production and IMAX DMR revenues decreased to $106.4&nbsp;million in 2016 from $107.1&nbsp;million in 2015. Gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	generated by
	IMAX DMR films decreased 2.1% to $965.6&nbsp;million in 2016 from $985.3&nbsp;million in 2015, which has a direct correlation with revenue. The Company experienced weaker gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	particularly in the
	China region resulting from both film performance and unfavourable exchange rates. Gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	per screen for 2016 averaged $963,800, in comparison to $1,155,800 in 2015. In 2016, gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	was generated primarily from the exhibition of 58&nbsp;films (51 new and 7 carryovers), as compared to 57 films (44 new and 13 carryover)&nbsp;exhibited in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other revenues attributable to the film segment increased 29.1% to $14.1&nbsp;million in 2016 from $10.9&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily due
	to an increase in film distribution revenue from IMAX original films. The year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, includes the release of two IMAX original productions,
<I>
	A
</I>
<I>
	Beautiful
</I>
<I>
	Planet
</I>
	and
<I>
	Voyage
</I>
<I>
	of
</I>
<I>
	Time
</I>
	,
	whereas no original films were released in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	61
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage62"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s gross margin from its film segments decreased 12.4% in 2016 to
	$69.0&nbsp;million from $78.8&nbsp;million in 2015. Film production and IMAX DMR gross margins decreased to $69.2&nbsp;million from $77.6&nbsp;million primarily due to higher costs, including marketing and post-production. Other gross margin
	attributable to the film segment was a loss of $0.2&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared to $1.1&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily due to a charge against film assets of $3.0&nbsp;million in 2016, to reflect the carrying value of certain documentary film
	assets that exceeded the expected revenues generated from estimated future
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office.
</FONT>
	No similar charge was recorded in 2015. This was partially offset by revenue earned from the release of two IMAX original
	productions,
<I>
	A
</I>
<I>
	Beautiful
</I>
<I>
	Planet
</I>
	and
<I>
	Voyage
</I>
<I>
	of
</I>
<I>
	Time
</I>
	, in the current year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Selling, General
	and Administrative Expenses
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Selling, general and administrative expenses increased to $124.7&nbsp;million in 2016, as compared to
	$115.3&nbsp;million in 2015. Selling, general and administrative expenses excluding the impact of stock-based compensation were $94.2&nbsp;million in 2016, as compared to $93.4&nbsp;million in 2015. The following reflects the significant items
	impacting selling, general and administrative expenses as compared to the prior year period:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	an $8.6&nbsp;million increase in the Company&#146;s stock-based compensation;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a $3.6&nbsp;million increase in staff costs related to the core business, including salaries and benefits; partially offset by
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a $1.5&nbsp;million decrease due to a change in foreign exchange rates. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company recorded a foreign exchange loss of $0.9&nbsp;million for net foreign exchange
	gains/losses related to the translation of foreign currency denominated monetary assets and liabilities as compared to a loss of $2.4&nbsp;million recorded in 2015. See note&nbsp;15(b) of the audited consolidated financial statements in Item&nbsp;8
	of the Company&#146;s 2016
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Form&nbsp;10-K
</FONT>
	for more information; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a $1.3&nbsp;million net decrease in other general corporate expenditures including professional fees, travel and entertainment.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Selling, general and administrative expenses also includes asset impairment charges and write-offs, if any, and miscellaneous items, other
	than interest
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Research and Development
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Research and development expenses increased to $16.3&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to $12.7&nbsp;million in 2015 and are primarily attributable
	to the continued development of the Company&#146;s new commercial laser-based digital projection system and other new business initiatives which commenced in 2016, including the Google camera and virtual reality. In 2014, the Company developed its
	next-generation laser-based digital projector, which provides greater brightness and clarity, higher contrast, a wider color gamut and deeper blacks, while consuming less power and lasting longer than existing digital technology, to ensure that the
	Company continues to provide the highest quality, premier movie going experience available to consumers. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had 39 laser-based digital theater systems in operation and 20 laser-based digital theater systems in
	backlog.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company intends for additional research and development to continue throughout 2017 as the Company supports further
	development of the commercial laser-based projection system. In addition to continued research and development with respect to its core business, the Company intends to continue research and development in connection with the previously-announced
	cinema-grade VR camera to be developed in partnership with Google. In 2016, the Company began research and development in connection with its exploration of a comprehensive VR strategy to deliver immersive and interactive experiences to consumers
	through pilot IMAX VR Centers, which the Company expects to continue in 2017. The Company also plans to conduct research and development activity in the future in other areas considered important to the Company&#146;s continued commercial success,
	including further improving the reliability of its projectors, developing and manufacturing more IMAX cameras, enhancing the Company&#146;s 2D and 3D image quality, expanding the applicability of the Company&#146;s digital technology, developing
	IMAX theater systems&#146; capabilities in both home and live entertainment, improvements to the DMR process and the ability to deliver DMR releases digitally to its theater network, without the requirement for hard drives.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	62
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage63"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Receivable Provisions, Net of Recoveries
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Receivable provisions, net of recoveries for accounts receivable and financing receivables amounted to a net provision of $1.0&nbsp;million in
	2016, as compared to $0.8&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s accounts receivables and financing receivables are subject to credit
	risk, as a result of geographical location, exchange rate fluctuations, and other unforeseeable financial difficulties. These receivables are concentrated with the leading theater exhibitors and studios in the film entertainment industry. To
	minimize the Company&#146;s credit risk, the Company retains title to underlying theater systems leased, performs initial and ongoing credit evaluations of its customers and makes ongoing provisions for its estimate of potentially uncollectible
	amounts. Accordingly, the Company believes it has adequately protected itself against exposures relating to receivables and contractual commitments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Asset Impairments and Other Charges
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recorded a charge related to property, plant and equipment of $0.2&nbsp;million and $0.4&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015,
	respectively, reflecting assets that no longer meet the capitalization requirements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, the Company recognized a $0.2&nbsp;million
	other-than-temporary impairment of its investments as the value is not expected to recover based on the length of time and extent to which the market value has been less than cost, as compared to $0.4&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Interest Income and Expense
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Interest income was $1.5&nbsp;million in 2016, as compared to $1.0&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Interest expense was $1.8&nbsp;million in 2016, as compared to $1.7&nbsp;million in 2015. Consistent with its historical financial reporting,
	the Company has elected to classify interest and penalties related to income tax liabilities, when applicable, as part of the interest expense in its consolidated statements of operations rather than income tax expense. In 2016 and 2015, the Company
	recovered less than $0.1&nbsp;million, respectively, in potential interest and penalties associated with its provision for uncertain tax positions. Also included in interest expense is the amortization of deferred finance costs in the amount of
	$0.5&nbsp;million and $1.0&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015, respectively. The Company&#146;s policy is to defer and amortize all the costs relating to debt financing which are paid directly to the debt provider, over the life of the debt instrument.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s effective tax rate differs from the statutory tax rate and varies from year to year primarily as a result of numerous
	permanent differences, investment and other tax credits, the provision for income taxes at different rates in foreign and other provincial jurisdictions, enacted statutory tax rate increases or reductions in the year, changes due to foreign
	exchange, changes in the Company&#146;s valuation allowance based on the Company&#146;s recoverability assessments of deferred tax assets, and favorable or unfavorable resolution of various tax examinations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s effective tax rate increased in 2016 due to changes in the mix of income in foreign jurisdictions and an increase in
	permanent differences as compared to 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recorded an income tax provision of $16.2&nbsp;million for 2016, of which
	$1.6&nbsp;million is related to a decrease in its provision for uncertain tax positions. For 2015, the Company recorded an income tax provision of $20.1&nbsp;million, of which $0.5&nbsp;million was related to an increase in its provision for
	uncertain tax positions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The provision for income taxes in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 includes a net income tax recovery of
	$0.1&nbsp;million (2015 &#150; less than $0.1&nbsp;million provision) in continuing operations related to a decrease in the valuation allowance for the Company&#146;s deferred tax assets and other tax adjustments. In 2015, the Company recorded an
	adjustment of $14.0&nbsp;million to the deferred tax assets, $5.9&nbsp;million to the income tax provision and $8.1&nbsp;million to shareholders&#146; equity related to tax benefits generated on the exercise of certain employee stock options. In
	conjunction with this, a provision for uncertain tax positions of $3.9&nbsp;million was also recorded to the income tax provision and $7.9&nbsp;million was recorded against shareholders&#146; equity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, after considering all available evidence, both positive (including recent profits, projected
	future profitability, backlog, carry forward periods for, and utilization of net operating loss carryovers and tax credits, discretionary deductions and other factors) and negative (including cumulative losses in past years and other factors), the
	Company
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	63
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage64"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	concluded that the valuation allowance against the Company&#146;s deferred tax assets should decrease by $0.1&nbsp;million. The remaining $0.2&nbsp;million balance in the valuation allowance as
	at December&nbsp;31, 2016 is primarily attributable to certain U.S. state net operating loss carryovers that may expire without being utilized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s Chinese subsidiary has made certain enquiries of the Chinese State Administration of Taxation regarding the potential
	deductibility of&nbsp;certain stock based compensation for stock options issued by the Chinese subsidiary&#146;s parent company, IMAX China Holding, Inc. In addition, Chinese regulatory authorities responsible for capital and exchange controls will
	need to review and approve the proposed transactions before they can be completed. There may be a requirement for future investment of funds into China in order to secure the deduction. Should the Company proceed, any such future investment would
	come from existing capital invested in the IMAX China group of companies being redeployed amongst the IMAX China group of companies, including the Chinese subsidiary. The Company is unable to reliably estimate the magnitude of the related tax
	benefits at this time.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Equity-Accounted Investments
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company accounts for investments in new business ventures using the guidance of the FASB ASC 323. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the equity
	method of accounting is being utilized for investments with a total carrying value of $nil (December 31, 2015 &#151; $1.0 million). The Company&#146;s accumulated losses in excess of its equity investment were $0.5 million as at December 31, 2016,
	and are classified in Accrued and other liabilities. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, gross revenues, cost of revenue and net loss for these investments were $0.6&nbsp;million, $6.8&nbsp;million and $6.2&nbsp;million, respectively (2015
	&#151; $nil, $9.3&nbsp;million and $9.1&nbsp;million, respectively). The Company recorded its proportionate share of the net loss which amounted to $2.3&nbsp;million for 2016 as compared to $2.4&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-Controlling
</FONT>
	Interests
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements include the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest in the net
	income of IMAX China resulting from the IMAX China Investment and the IMAX China IPO as well as the impact of a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest in its subsidiary created for the Film Fund activity. For the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, the net income attributable to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-controlling
</FONT>
	interests of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries was $10.5&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $8.8 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Pension Plan
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	Company has an unfunded defined benefit pension plan, the Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (the &#147;SERP&#148;), covering the Company&#146;s CEO, Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had an unfunded and accrued
	projected benefit obligation of approximately $19.6&nbsp;million (December 31, 2015&nbsp;&#151; $19.5&nbsp;million) in respect of the SERP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The net periodic benefit cost was $0.3&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015, respectively. The components of net periodic benefit cost were as
	follows:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The plan experienced an actuarial gain of $0.2&nbsp;million during 2016 and 2015, respectively, resulting
	primarily from the continuing change in the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (&#147;PBGC&#148;) published annuity interest rates year-over-year used to determine the lump sum payment under the plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under the terms of the SERP, if Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond&#146;s employment is terminated other than for cause (as defined in his employment
	agreement), he is entitled to receive SERP benefits in the form of a lump sum payment. SERP benefit payments to Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond are subject to a deferral for six months after the termination of his employment, at which time Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond will be
	entitled to receive interest on the deferred amount credited at the applicable federal rate for short-term obligations. Pursuant to an employment agreement dated November&nbsp;8, 2016, the term of Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond&#146;s employment was extended
	through December&nbsp;31, 2019, although Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond has not informed the Company that he intends to retire at that time. Under the terms of the arrangement, no compensation earned beginning in 2011 is to be included in calculating this
	entitlement under the SERP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has a postretirement plan to provide health and welfare benefits to Canadian employees meeting
	certain eligibility requirements. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had an unfunded benefit obligation of $1.7&nbsp;million (December 31, 2015&nbsp;&#151; $1.8&nbsp;million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In July 2000, the Company agreed to maintain health benefits for Messrs. Gelfond and Bradley J.
	Wechsler, the Company&#146;s former
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Co-CEO
</FONT>
	and current Chairman of its Board of Directors, upon retirement. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had an unfunded benefit obligation recorded of
	$0.6&nbsp;million (December 31, 2015 &#151; $0.8 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In September 2016, the Company entered into a new employment agreement with
	Greg Foster, CEO of IMAX Entertainment and Senior Executive Vice President of the Company, which provides for an employment term from July&nbsp;2, 2016 through July&nbsp;2, 2019. Under the agreement, the Company agreed to create a deferred
	compensation retirement plan (the &#147;Retirement Plan&#148;) covering Mr.&nbsp;Foster, and to make a total contribution of $3.2&nbsp;million over the three-year employment term. The Retirement Plan is subject to a vesting schedule based on
	continued employment with the Company, such that 25% will vest July 2019; 50% will vest July 2022; 75% will vest July 2025; and Mr. Foster will be 100% vested in July 2027. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had an unfunded benefit obligation
	recorded of $0.5&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Stock-Based Compensation
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company estimates the fair value of stock option awards on the date of grant using fair value measurement techniques. The fair value of RSU
	awards is equal to the closing price of the Company&#146;s common stock on the date of grant.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Stock-based compensation expense recognized
	under FASB ASC 718, &#147;Compensation &#150; Stock Compensation&#148; (&#147;ASC 718&#148;) for 2016 and 2015 was $30.5&nbsp;million and $21.9&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage66"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Year Ended December 31, 2015 versus Year Ended December 31, 2014
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company reported net income of $64.6&nbsp;million, or $0.92 per basic share and $0.90 per diluted share, for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 as compared to net income of $42.2&nbsp;million, or $0.61 per basic share and $0.59 per diluted share, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. Net income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 includes a
	$21.9&nbsp;million charge, or $0.31 per diluted share (2014 &#151; $15.1&nbsp;million, or $0.22 per diluted share), for stock-based compensation. Adjusted net income, which consists of net income excluding the impact of stock-based compensation and
	the related tax impact, was $82.4&nbsp;million, or $1.15 per diluted share, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 as compared to adjusted net income of $54.9&nbsp;million, or $0.78 per diluted share, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
	The Company reported net income attributable to common shareholders of $55.8&nbsp;million, or $0.79 per basic share and $0.78 per diluted share for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 (2014&nbsp;&#151; $39.7&nbsp;million, or $0.57 per basic share
	and $0.56 per diluted share). Adjusted net income attributable to common shareholders, which consists of net income attributable to common shareholders excluding the impact of stock-based compensation and the related tax impact, was
	$73.0&nbsp;million, or $1.02 per diluted share, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 as compared to adjusted net income attributable to common shareholders of $52.5&nbsp;million, or $0.75 per diluted share, for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2014. A reconciliation of net income and net income attributable to common shareholders, the most directly comparable U.S. GAAP measure, to adjusted net income, adjusted net income per diluted share, adjusted net income attributable to common
	shareholders and adjusted net income attributable to common shareholders per diluted share is presented in the table below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)

<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes impact of $0.8&nbsp;million (2014 &#151; $0.4 million) of accretion charges associated with redeemable Class&nbsp;C shares of IMAX China.
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Revenues and Gross Margin
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s revenues for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 increased 28.7% to $373.8&nbsp;million from $290.5&nbsp;million in 2014,
	primarily due to an increase in revenues from the Company&#146;s IMAX systems, joint revenue sharing arrangements and film production and IMAX DMR segments. The gross margin across all segments in 2015 was $219.3&nbsp;million, or 58.7% of total
	revenue, compared to $173.4&nbsp;million, or 59.7% of total revenue in 2014. Impacting the gross margin in 2015 was the installation of 10 laser-based digital upgrades under sales or sales-type lease arrangements which had lower margins. Gross
	margin, excluding the impact of these laser-based digital upgrades, was 60.9% of total revenue in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	IMAX Systems
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	IMAX systems revenue increased 40.6% to $119.7&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared to $85.1&nbsp;million in 2014 resulting primarily from the
	installation in 2015 of nine additional full, new theater systems and 11 digital upgrades including 10 laser-based digital upgrades and one xenon-based digital upgrade under sales or sales-type lease arrangements versus the prior year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from sales and sales-type leases increased 47.7% to $86.9&nbsp;million in 2015 from $58.9&nbsp;million in 2014. The Company recognized
	revenue on 55 full, new theater systems which qualified as either sales or sales-type leases in 2015, with a total value of $68.6&nbsp;million, versus 46 full, new theater systems in 2014 with a total value of $55.6&nbsp;million. The Company also
	recognized revenue on the installation of 11 theater system upgrades in 2015, of which 10 were laser-based and one was xenon-based, with a total value of
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	66
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage67"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	$15.0&nbsp;million, as compared to three xenon-based digital upgrades in 2014, with a total value of $2.3&nbsp;million. Theater system upgrades typically have lower sales prices and gross margin
	than full, new theater system installations. One used xenon-based digital system was installed in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 with a total value of $0.2&nbsp;million while&nbsp;&nbsp;no used systems were installed and recognized in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Average revenue per full, new sales and sales-type lease systems was $1.2&nbsp;million in 2015, which was consistent with the prior year.
	The average revenue per full, new sales and sales-type lease systems varies depending upon the number of theater system commitments with a single respective exhibitor, an exhibitor&#146;s location or other various factors. Average revenue per
	theater system upgrade was $1.4&nbsp;million in 2015, as compared to $0.8&nbsp;million in 2014. For 2015, the average revenue per upgrade was higher as 10 of the 11 system upgrades were for laser-based digital system configurations which are priced
	higher than xenon-based digital upgrades.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The installation of theater systems in newly-built theaters or multiplexes, which make up a
	large portion of the Company&#146;s theater system backlog, depends primarily on the timing of the construction of those projects, which is not under the Company&#146;s control. The breakdown in mix of sales and sales-type lease and joint revenue
	sharing arrangements (see discussion below) installations by theater system configuration for 2015 and 2014 is outlined in the table below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:1.00PX SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes 17 laser-based digital system configurations (one new&nbsp;laser-based digital system under a sales arrangement and 16
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	laser-based
</FONT>
	digital&nbsp;system upgrades, 10 under
	sales arrangements, one under a short-term operating lease arrangement and five under joint revenue sharing arrangements).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Reflects xenon-based digital system configurations under short-term operating lease arrangements, which will be upgraded to a laser-based digital system configuration at a future date.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenues from sales and sales-type leases include settlement revenue of $0.1&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared to $nil in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	IMAX theater system margin from full, new sales and sales-type lease systems, excluding the impact of settlements, was 65.9% in 2015, which
	was higher than the 63.4% experienced in 2014. Gross margin from theater system upgrades was $0.8&nbsp;million in 2015, as compared to $1.2&nbsp;million in 2014. In addition, the Company recorded a charge of $0.7&nbsp;million upon the upgrade of
	xenon-based digital systems under operating lease arrangements to laser-based digital systems under sales or sales-type lease arrangements in IMAX Systems margin. Furthermore, included in IMAX systems margin is a charge of $0.1&nbsp;million and
	$0.2&nbsp;million in 2015 and 2014, respectively, due to a reduction in the net realizable value of its inventories. Gross margin varies depending upon the number of theater system commitments with a single respective exhibitor, an exhibitor&#146;s
	location and other various factors. Gross margin from the sale of a used system was a loss of $0.2&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared to $nil in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, due to change in agreement terms, an IMAX theater that had been operating under a joint revenue sharing arrangement became a
	sales-type lease arrangement. As a result of this transaction, the Company recorded revenue and margin of $1.2&nbsp;million and $0.9&nbsp;million, respectively. Furthermore, one of the Company&#146;s customers acquired an IMAX theater from another
	customer that had been operating under an operating lease arrangement. This theater was purchased from the Company under a sale arrangement. As result of this sale transaction, the Company recorded revenue and margin of $0.8&nbsp;million and
	$0.4&nbsp;million, respectively. The above-referenced theaters were included in the Company&#146;s 2014 network total.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	67
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage68"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2014, the Company donated, and recognized the associated costs, of a full, new xenon-based
	digital theater system to the University of Southern California&#146;s School of Cinematic Arts. The theater, which is the first teaching lab of its kind in a collegiate setting, will give students the opportunity to learn about the latest
	innovations in filmmaking, set design, sound and post-production.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Ongoing rent revenue and finance income increased to $15.2&nbsp;million
	in 2015 compared to $14.1&nbsp;million in 2014. Gross margin for ongoing rent and finance income increased to $14.4&nbsp;million in 2015 compared to $13.4&nbsp;million in 2014. Contingent fees included in this caption amounted to $3.8&nbsp;million
	and $3.0&nbsp;million in 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other revenue increased to $17.6&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared to
	$12.2&nbsp;million in 2014. Other revenue primarily includes revenue generated from the Company&#146;s theater operations, camera rental business and after-market sales of projection system parts and 3D glasses. The growth in revenue is primarily
	the result of an increase in revenue from 3D glasses and higher
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	generated by the films exhibited in the IMAX owned and operated theaters during 2015 as compared to the prior year period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The gross margin recognized from other revenue increased to $0.3&nbsp;million 2015, as compared to $0.1&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Theater System Maintenance
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Theater system maintenance revenue increased 8.5% to $36.9&nbsp;million in 2015 from $34.0&nbsp;million in 2014. Theater system maintenance
	gross margin increased to $12.7&nbsp;million in 2015 from $12.4&nbsp;million in 2014. The Company recorded a write-down of less than $0.1&nbsp;million and $0.2&nbsp;million for certain service parts inventories in 2015 and 2014, respectively.
	Maintenance revenue continues to grow as the number of theaters in the IMAX theater network grows. Maintenance margins vary depending on the mix of theater system configurations in the theater network, volume-pricing related to larger relationships
	and the timing and the date(s) of installation and/or service.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Joint Revenue Sharing Arrangements
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenues from joint revenue sharing arrangements increased 44.9% to $99.1&nbsp;million in 2015 from $68.4&nbsp;million in 2014. The Company
	ended the year with 529 theaters operating under joint revenue sharing arrangements, as compared to 451 theaters at the end of 2014, an increase of 17.3%. The increase in revenues from joint revenue sharing arrangements was largely due to the
	greater number of theaters under joint revenue sharing arrangements in operation as compared to the prior year and stronger film performance. During 2015, the Company installed 80 full, new theaters under joint revenue sharing arrangements, as
	compared to 67 full new theaters during 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The gross margin from joint revenue sharing arrangements was $68.4&nbsp;million in 2015 as
	compared to $44.7&nbsp;million in 2014. Included in the calculation of the 2015 gross margin were certain advertising, marketing and commission costs primarily associated with new theater launches of $4.3&nbsp;million, as compared to
	$3.2&nbsp;million for such expenses in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Film
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from the Company&#146;s film segments increased $118.0&nbsp;million in 2015 and $102.9&nbsp;million in 2014 primarily due to stronger
	film performance and continued network growth. Gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	generated by IMAX DMR films increased 31.3% to $985.3&nbsp;million in 2015 from $750.2&nbsp;million in 2014. With the addition of gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	from IMAX original films, the Company&#146;s gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	exceeded $1&nbsp;billion in 2015. Film production and IMAX DMR revenues increased 28.8% to
	$107.1&nbsp;million in 2015 from $83.2&nbsp;million in 2014. Gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	per screen for 2015 averaged $1,155,800 in comparison to $1,020,600 in 2014. In 2015, gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	was generated primarily from the exhibition of 57 films (44 new and 13 carryovers), as compared to 50 films (40 new and 10 carryover) exhibited in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other revenues attributable to the film segment decreased 44.6% to $10.9&nbsp;million in 2015 from $19.8&nbsp;million in 2014. This decrease
	was attributable to the wide release of two IMAX original productions,
<I>
	Journey
</I>
<I>
	to
</I>
<I>
	the
</I>
<I>
	South
</I>
<I>
	Pacific
</I>
	and
<I>
	Island
</I>
<I>
	of
</I>
<I>
	Lemurs:
</I>
<I>
	Madagascar
</I>
	, in 2014, whereas in 2015, the Company did not
	release any IMAX original productions as well as a decrease in post-production revenues as compared to the prior year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s
	gross margin from its film segments increased 15.4% in 2015 to $78.8&nbsp;million from $68.2&nbsp;million in 2014. Film production and IMAX DMR gross margins increased to $77.6&nbsp;million from $62.9&nbsp;million primarily due to continued network
	growth and stronger film performance. Other gross margin attributable to the film segment was $1.1&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared to $5.3&nbsp;million in 2014, since no original productions were released in 2015, as described above, and a decrease
	in post-production business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	68
</P>

</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Selling, general and administrative expenses increased to $115.3&nbsp;million in 2015, as compared to $93.3&nbsp;million in 2014. Selling,
	general and administrative expenses excluding the impact of stock-based compensation were $93.4&nbsp;million in 2015, as compared to $78.1&nbsp;million in 2014. The following reflects the significant items impacting selling, general and
	administrative expenses as compared to the prior year period:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	an $8.8&nbsp;million increase in staff costs related to the core business, including salaries and benefits and certain incentive awards based on the Company&#146;s performance, the completion of the IMAX China IPO, and
	the achievement of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-determined
</FONT>
	performance metrics;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</TD>

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a $6.8&nbsp;million increase in the Company&#146;s stock-based compensation;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</TD>

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a $2.6&nbsp;million net increase in staff costs and other expenses associated with new business initiatives, from $0.7&nbsp;million in 2014 to $3.3&nbsp;million in 2015;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a $0.9&nbsp;million increase due to a change in foreign exchange rates. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company recorded a foreign exchange loss of $2.4&nbsp;million for net foreign exchange
	gains/losses related to the translation of foreign currency denominated monetary assets and liabilities as compared to a loss of $1.5&nbsp;million recorded in 2014;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a $0.8&nbsp;million net increase in advertising and promotion related activities; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a $2.1&nbsp;million net increase in other general corporate expenditures including an increase in consulting and other professional fees and costs associated with the IMAX China IPO.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Research and Development
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Research and development expenses decreased to $12.7&nbsp;million in 2015 compared to $16.1&nbsp;million in 2014 and are primarily attributable
	to the development of the Company&#146;s new laser-based digital projection system and its new private home theater. In 2014, the Company developed its next-generation laser-based digital projector, which provides greater brightness and clarity,
	higher contrast, a wider color gamut and deeper blacks, while consuming less power and lasting longer than existing digital technology, to ensure that the company continues to provide the highest quality, premier movie going experience available to
	consumers. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company had 18 laser-based digital theater systems in operation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Receivable
	Provisions, Net of Recoveries
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Receivable provisions, net of recoveries for accounts receivable and financing receivables amounted
	to a net provision of $0.8&nbsp;million in 2015, as compared to $0.9&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s accounts receivables and
	financing receivables are subject to credit risk. These receivables are concentrated with the leading theater exhibitors and studios in the film entertainment industry. To minimize the Company&#146;s credit risk, the Company retains title to
	underlying theater systems leased, performs initial and ongoing credit evaluations of its customers and makes ongoing provisions for its estimate of potentially uncollectible amounts. Accordingly, the Company believes it has adequately protected
	itself against exposures relating to receivables and contractual commitments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Asset Impairments and Other Charges
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recorded an asset impairment charge of $0.4&nbsp;million and $0.3&nbsp;million in 2015 and 2014, respectively, against property,
	plant and equipment after the Company assessed the carrying value of certain assets in light of their future expected cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In
	2015, the Company recognized a $0.4&nbsp;million other-than-temporary impairment of its investments as the value is not expected to recover based on the length of time and extent to which the market value has been less than cost as compared to
	$3.2&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	69
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage70"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015 and 2014, the Company recorded a charge of $0.3&nbsp;million and $0.5&nbsp;million,
	respectively, reflecting assets that no longer meet capitalization requirements as the assets were no longer in use.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Interest
	Income and Expense
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Interest income was $1.0&nbsp;million in 2015, as compared to $0.4&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Interest expense was $1.7&nbsp;million in 2015, as compared to $0.9&nbsp;million in 2014. Consistent with its historical financial reporting,
	the Company has elected to classify interest and penalties related to income tax liabilities, when applicable, as part of the interest expense in its consolidated statements of operations rather than income tax expense. In 2015 and 2014, the Company
	recovered less than $0.1&nbsp;million, respectively, in potential interest and penalties associated with its provision for uncertain tax positions. Also included in interest expense is the amortization of deferred finance costs in the amount of
	$1.0&nbsp;million and $0.5&nbsp;million in 2015 and 2014, respectively. The Company&#146;s policy is to defer and amortize all the costs relating to debt financing which are paid directly to the debt provider, over the life of the debt instrument.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s effective tax rate differs from the statutory tax rate and varies from year to year primarily as a result of numerous
	permanent differences, investment and other tax credits, the provision for income taxes at different rates in foreign and other provincial jurisdictions, enacted statutory tax rate increases or reductions in the year, changes due to foreign
	exchange, changes in the Company&#146;s valuation allowance based on the Company&#146;s recoverability assessments of deferred tax assets, and favorable or unfavorable resolution of various tax examinations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recorded an income tax provision of $20.1&nbsp;million for 2015, of which $0.5&nbsp;million is related to an increase in its
	provision for uncertain tax positions. For 2014, the Company recorded an income tax provision of $14.5&nbsp;million, of which $0.2&nbsp;million was related to a decrease in its provision for uncertain tax positions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The provision for income taxes in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 includes a net income tax charge of less than $0.1&nbsp;million (2014
	&#151; $0.4&nbsp;million recovery) in continuing operations related to an increase in the valuation allowance for the Company&#146;s deferred tax assets and other tax adjustments. In 2015, the Company recorded an adjustment of $14.0&nbsp;million to
	the deferred tax assets, $5.9&nbsp;million to the income tax provision and $8.1&nbsp;million to shareholders&#146; equity related to tax benefits generated on the exercise of certain employee stock options. In conjunction with this, a provision for
	uncertain tax positions of $3.9&nbsp;million was also recorded to the income tax provision and $7.9&nbsp;million was recorded against shareholders&#146; equity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, after considering all available evidence, both positive (including recent profits, projected
	future profitability, backlog, carry forward periods for, and utilization of net operating loss carryovers and tax credits, discretionary deductions and other factors) and negative (including cumulative losses in past years and other factors), the
	Company concluded that the valuation allowance against the Company&#146;s deferred tax assets should increase by less than $0.1&nbsp;million. The remaining $0.3&nbsp;million balance in the valuation allowance as at December&nbsp;31, 2015 is
	primarily attributable to certain U.S. state net operating loss carryovers that may expire without being utilized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Equity-Accounted
	Investments
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company accounts for investments in new business ventures using the guidance of the FASB ASC 323. At
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, the equity method of accounting is being utilized for investments with a total carrying value of $1.0&nbsp;million (December&nbsp;31, 2014 &#151; $2.8 million). For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, gross revenues, cost
	of revenue and net loss for these investments were $nil, $9.3&nbsp;million and $9.1&nbsp;million, respectively (2014 &#151; $3.1&nbsp;million, $5.9&nbsp;million and $4.9&nbsp;million, respectively). The Company recorded its proportionate share of
	the net loss which amounted to $2.4&nbsp;million for 2015 compared to $1.1&nbsp;million in 2014. In 2014, the Company recognized a gain of $0.1&nbsp;million resulting from the sale of its interest in an equity-accounted investment. No such
	transactions were recorded in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Discontinued Operations
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On January&nbsp;30, 2014, the Company&#146;s lease with respect to its owned and operated Nyack IMAX theater ended and the Company decided not
	to renew the lease. In 2014, revenues for the Nyack IMAX theater were less than $0.1&nbsp;million and the Company recognized income of $0.4&nbsp;million, net of a tax expense of $0.2&nbsp;million from the operation of the theater. The transactions
	of the Company&#146;s owned and operated Nyack theater are reflected as discontinued operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	70
</P>

</FONT>
	Interests
</I>
</B>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements include the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest in the net
	income of IMAX China resulting from the IMAX China Investment and the IMAX China IPO as well as the impact of a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">

</FONT>
	interest in its subsidiary created for the Film Fund activity. For the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, the net income attributable to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-controlling
</FONT>
	interests of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries was $8.8&nbsp;million (2014 &#151; $2.4 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Pension Plan
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	Company has an unfunded defined benefit pension plan, the SERP, covering Messrs. Gelfond and Bradley J. Wechsler, the Company&#146;s former
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Co-CEO
</FONT>
	and Chairman of its Board of Directors. As at
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company had an unfunded and accrued projected benefit obligation of approximately $19.5&nbsp;million (December 31, 2014 &#151; $19.4 million) in respect of the SERP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The net periodic benefit cost was $0.3&nbsp;million in 2015 and 2014, respectively. The components of net periodic benefit cost were as
	follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The plan experienced an actuarial gain of $0.2&nbsp;million and an actuarial loss of $0.9&nbsp;million during
	2015 and 2014, respectively, resulting primarily from the continuing change in the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (&#147;PBGC&#148;) published annuity interest rates year-over-year used to determine the lump sum payment under the plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under the terms of the SERP, if Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond&#146;s employment is terminated other than for cause (as defined in his employment
	agreement), he is entitled to receive SERP benefits in the form of a lump sum payment. SERP benefit payments to Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond are subject to a deferral for six months after the termination of his employment, at which time Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond will be
	entitled to receive interest on the deferred amount credited at the applicable federal rate for short-term obligations. Pursuant to an employment agreement dated November&nbsp;8, 2016, the term of Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond&#146;s employment was extended
	through December&nbsp;31, 2019, although Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond has not informed the Company that he intends to retire at that time. Under the terms of the arrangement, no compensation earned beginning in 2011 is to be included in calculating this
	entitlement under the SERP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has a postretirement plan to provide health and welfare benefits to Canadian employees meeting
	certain eligibility requirements. As at December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company had an unfunded benefit obligation of $1.8&nbsp;million (December 31, 2014 &#151; $2.1 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In July 2000, the Company agreed to maintain health benefits for Messrs. Gelfond and Wechsler upon retirement. As at December&nbsp;31, 2015,
	the Company had an unfunded benefit obligation recorded of $0.8&nbsp;million (December 31, 2014 &#151; $0.8 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Stock-Based
	Compensation
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company estimates the fair value of stock option and SAR awards on the date of grant using fair value measurement
	techniques. The fair value of RSU awards is equal to the closing price of the Company&#146;s common stock on the date of grant.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Stock-based compensation expense recognized under FASB ASC 718, &#147;Compensation &#150; Stock Compensation&#148; (&#147;ASC 718&#148;) for
	2015 and 2014 was $21.9&nbsp;million and $15.1&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	71

<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">

</A>
</H5>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Credit Facility
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company maintains a
	senior secured credit facility (the &#147;Credit Facility&#148;) with a maximum borrowing capacity of $200.0&nbsp;million and a scheduled maturity of March&nbsp;3, 2020. The Credit Facility is collateralized by a first priority security interest in
	substantially all of the present and future assets of the Company and the Guarantors. Certain of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries serve as guarantors (the &#147;Guarantors&#148;) of the Company&#146;s obligations under the Credit Facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The terms of the Credit Facility are set forth in the Fourth Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (the &#147;Credit Agreement&#148;), dated
	March&nbsp;3, 2015, among the Company, the Guarantors, the lenders named therein, Wells Fargo Bank, National Association (&#147;Wells Fargo&#148;), as agent and issuing lender (Wells Fargo, together with the lenders named therein, the
	&#147;Lenders&#148;) and Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, as Sole Lead Arranger and Sole Bookrunner and in various collateral and security documents entered into by the Company and the Guarantors. Each of the Guarantors has also entered into a guarantee
	in respect of the Company&#146;s obligations under the Credit Facility. On February&nbsp;22, 2016, the Company amended the terms of the Credit Agreement to increase the general restricted payment basket thereunder (which covers, among other things,
	the repurchase of shares) from $150.0&nbsp;million to $350.0&nbsp;million in the aggregate after the amendment date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total amounts drawn
	and available under the Credit Facility at December&nbsp;31, 2016 were $nil and $200.0&nbsp;million, respectively (December 31, 2015 &#150; $nil and $200.0&nbsp;million, respectively).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under the Credit Facility, the effective interest rate for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was nil, as no amounts were outstanding
	during the period (2015 &#150; nil).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Credit Agreement provides that the Company is required at all times to satisfy a Minimum
	Liquidity Test (as defined in the Credit Agreement) of at least $50.0&nbsp;million. The Company is also required to maintain minimum Adjusted EBITDA (as defined in the Credit Agreement as EBITDA and referred to herein as Adjusted EBITDA) of
	$100.0&nbsp;million. The Company is also required to maintain a Maximum Total Leverage Ratio (as defined in the Credit Agreement) of 2.0:1.0, which requirement decreases to 1.75:1.0 on December&nbsp;31, 2017. The Company was in compliance with all
	of these requirements at December&nbsp;31, 2016. The Maximum Total Leverage Ratio was 0.23:1 as at December&nbsp;31, 2016, where Total Debt (as defined in the Credit Agreement) is the sum of all obligations evidenced by notes, bonds, debentures or
	similar instruments and was $27.7&nbsp;million.&nbsp;Adjusted EBITDA is calculated as follows:
</P>
