	considering adopting the new standard using the modified retrospective method and has begun the process of gathering historical information on its contracts in preparation for the standard&#146;s expanded disclosure requirements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-13,
</FONT>
	&#147;Financial Instruments &#150; Credit Losses
	(Topic 326): Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments&#148; (&#147;ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-13&#148;).
</FONT>
	The purpose of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-13
</FONT>
	is to require a financial asset measured
	on the amortized cost basis to be presented at the net amount expected to be collected. Credit losses relating to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	available-for-sale
</FONT>
</FONT>
	debt securities should be recorded
	through an allowance for credit losses. For public entities, the amendments in ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-13
</FONT>
	are effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2019. The Company is
	currently assessing the impact of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-13
</FONT>
	on its consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In
	October 2016, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-16,
</FONT>
	&#147;Income Taxes (Topic 740)&#148;. The purpose of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-16
</FONT>
	is to eliminate the exception for an intra-entity
	transfer of an asset other than inventory. The amendments require the recognition of the income tax consequences of an intra-entity transfer of an asset, other than inventory, when the transfer occurs. For public entities, the amendments in ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-16
</FONT>
	are effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2017. The Company is currently assessing the impact of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-16
</FONT>
	on its
	consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In October 2016, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-17,
</FONT>
	&#147;Consolidation (Topic 810)&#148;. The purpose of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-17
</FONT>
	is to update the requirement of the reporting entity, in determining whether it satisfies the second characteristic of a primary beneficiary,
	to include all of its direct variable interests in a VIE and, on a proportionate basis, its indirect variable interests in a VIE held through related parties, including related parties that are under common control with the reporting entity. For
	public entities, the amendments in ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-17
</FONT>
	are effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2016. While the Company continues to evaluate the effect of the standard
	on its ongoing financial reporting, the adoption of this guidance will not have any effect on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Recently issued FASB accounting standard codification updates, except for the above noted standards, were not material to the Company&#146;s
	consolidated financial statements for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	100
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage101"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	4.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Lease Arrangements
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(a)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	General Terms of Lease Arrangements
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	A number of the Company&#146;s leases are
	classified as sales-type leases. Certain arrangements that are legal sales are also classified as sales-type leases as certain clauses within the arrangements limit transfer of title or provide the Company with conditional rights to the system. The
	customer&#146;s rights under the Company&#146;s lease arrangements are described in note&nbsp;2(m). The Company classifies its lease arrangements at inception of the arrangement and, if required, after a modification of the lease arrangement, to
	determine whether they are sales-type leases or operating leases. Under the Company&#146;s lease arrangements, the customer has the ability and the right to operate the hardware components or direct others to operate them in a manner determined by
	the customer. The Company&#146;s lease portfolio terms are typically
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cancellable
</FONT>
	for 10 to 20 years with renewal provisions from inception. Except for those sales arrangements that are classified as
	sales-type leases, the Company&#146;s leases generally do not contain an automatic transfer of title at the end of the lease term. The Company&#146;s lease arrangements do not contain a guarantee of residual value at the end of the lease term. The
	customer is required to pay for executory costs such as insurance and taxes and is required to pay the Company for maintenance and extended warranty generally after the first year of the lease until the end of the lease term. The customer is
	responsible for obtaining insurance coverage for the theater systems commencing on the date specified in the arrangement&#146;s shipping terms and ending on the date the theater systems are delivered back to the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has assessed the nature of its joint revenue sharing arrangements and concluded that, based on the guidance in the Revenue
	Recognition Topic of the ASC, the arrangements contain a lease. Under joint revenue sharing arrangements, the customer has the ability and the right to operate the hardware components or direct others to operate them in a manner determined by the
	customer. The Company&#146;s joint revenue sharing arrangements are typically
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cancellable
</FONT>
	for 10 years or longer with renewal provisions. Title to equipment under joint revenue sharing arrangements does
	not transfer to the customer. The Company&#146;s joint revenue sharing arrangements do not contain a guarantee of residual value at the end of the term. The customer is required to pay for executory costs such as insurance and taxes and is required
	to pay the Company for maintenance and extended warranty throughout the term. The customer is responsible for obtaining insurance coverage for the theater systems commencing on the date specified in the arrangement&#146;s shipping terms and ending
	on the date the theater systems are delivered back to the Company. See additional details regarding the Company&#146;s traditional and hybrid joint revenue sharing arrangements as described in note&nbsp;2(m).
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(b)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Financing Receivables
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Financing receivables, consisting of net investment in
	sales-type leases and receivables from financed sales of theater systems are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, finished goods inventory for which title had passed to the customer and revenue was
	deferred amounted to $2.3&nbsp;million (December 31, 2015&nbsp;&#151; $5.4&nbsp;million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Inventories at December&nbsp;31, 2016 include
	impairments and write-downs for excess and obsolete inventory based upon current estimates of net realizable value considering future events and conditions of $0.5&nbsp;million (December 31, 2015&nbsp;&#151; $0.6&nbsp;million).
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company expects to amortize film costs of $4.8&nbsp;million for released films within three years from
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 (December 31, 2015&nbsp;&#151; $6.3&nbsp;million), including $2.4&nbsp;million, which reflects the portion of the costs of the Company&#146;s completed films that are expected to be amortized within the next year. The amount
	of participation payments to third parties related to these films that the Company expects to pay during 2017, which is included in accrued liabilities at December&nbsp;31, 2016, is $4.2&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $3.9 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recorded a charge of $3.0 million (2015 &#151; $nil) in costs and expenses applicable to revenues &#151; services, after an
	assessment of the carrying value of certain documentary films and their estimated future box-office was performed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recognized asset impairment charges of $0.2&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $0.4&nbsp;million, 2014
	&#151; $0.3&nbsp;million) against property, plant and equipment after an assessment of the carrying value of certain assets in light of their future expected cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Included in theater system components are assets with costs of $10.3&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $11.5&nbsp;million) and accumulated depreciation of $8.1&nbsp;million (2015&nbsp;&#151; $7.3 million) that are leased to
	customers under operating leases.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Included in theater system components are assets with costs of $205.2&nbsp;million (2015&nbsp;&#151; $178.0&nbsp;million) and accumulated depreciation of $75.7&nbsp;million (2015&nbsp;&#151; $62.2&nbsp;million) that are
	used in joint revenue sharing arrangements.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	In 2016, the Company identified and wrote off $0.6&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $1.1 million) of theater system components upon the upgrade of xenon-based digital systems under operating lease arrangements to laser-based
	digital systems under sales or sales-type lease arrangements. In 2016, the Company recorded $nil (2015 &#151; $2.2 million) related to theater system components that are no longer in use and fully amortized.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	During 2016, the Company signed certain amending agreements which increased the length of the term for all applicable existing and future theaters under joint revenue sharing arrangement. As a result, the Company
	adjusted the estimated useful life of its theater system components in use for those respective joint revenue sharing theaters, on a prospective basis, to reflect the change in term. This resulted in decreased depreciation expense of
	$0.1&nbsp;million in 2016 and $1.0&nbsp;million in each of the next 5 years since the Systems will now be depreciated over a longer useful life.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(5)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Included in assets under construction are components with costs of $8.6&nbsp;million (2015&nbsp;&#151; $6.0&nbsp;million) that will be utilized to construct assets to be used in joint revenue sharing arrangements.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(6)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Fully amortized office and production equipment is still in use by the Company. In 2016, the Company identified and wrote off $0.7&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $3.1 million) of office and production equipment that is no
	longer in use and fully amortized.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	104
</P>

<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company has decreased the valuation allowance by $0.1&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; less than $0.1&nbsp;million increase) relating to the future utilization of deductible
	temporary differences, tax credits, and certain net operating loss carryforwards. Also included in the provision for income taxes is the deferred tax related to amounts recorded in and reclassified from other comprehensive income in the year of
	$1.2&nbsp;million.
</TD>
</TR>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The gross deferred tax assets include an asset of $0.1&nbsp;million relating to the remaining tax effect
	resulting from the Company&#146;s defined benefit pension plan, the related actuarial gains and losses, and unrealized net gains and losses on cash flow hedging instruments recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09,
</FONT>
	related to stock-based compensation, was issued in March 2016 and early adopted by the
	Company in June 2016. ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09
</FONT>
	eliminates additional paid in capital (&#147;APIC&#148;) pools and requires excess tax benefits and tax deficiencies to be recorded in the consolidated statements of
	operations when the awards vest or are settled. Amendments related to accounting for excess tax benefits have been adopted prospectively resulting in a tax benefit of $0.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016. In addition, modified
	retrospective adoption of ASC
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09
</FONT>
	eliminates the requirement that excess tax benefits be realized before they can be recognized. The Company has also recorded a cumulative-effect adjustment of
	$0.9&nbsp;million to Accumulated earnings and Deferred income taxes related to the impact from adoption of the provisions related to forfeiture rates. See notes 3 and 14 for further discussion of the impact from the adoption of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, the Company recorded an adjustment of $14.0&nbsp;million to deferred tax assets,
	$5.9&nbsp;million to the income tax provision and $8.1&nbsp;million to shareholders&#146; equity related to excess tax benefits generated on the exercise of certain employee stock options. In conjunction with this, a provision for uncertain tax
	positions of $3.9&nbsp;million was recorded to income tax provision and $7.9&nbsp;million was recorded against shareholders&#146; equity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year, the Company and its subsidiaries completed a number of intra-entity sales of assets. The Company has deferred or eliminated
	the related tax expense and deferred taxes specifically associated with such intra-entity transfers, and is included in Other Assets as disclosed in note 8.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has not provided Canadian taxes on cumulative earnings of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-Canadian
</FONT>
	affiliates and
	associated companies that have been reinvested indefinitely. Taxes are provided for earnings of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-Canadian
</FONT>
	affiliates and associated companies when the Company determines that such earnings are no longer
	indefinitely reinvested.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	107
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Estimated net operating loss carryforwards of $17.6&nbsp;million can be carried forward to reduce taxable
	income through to 2037 and the remaining $20.1&nbsp;million can be carried forward indefinitely. Investment tax credits and other tax credits can be carried forward to reduce income taxes payable through to 2037.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(f) Valuation allowance
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	provision for income taxes in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 includes a net income tax recovery of $0.1&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; less than $0.1&nbsp;million expense) in continuing operations related to a decrease in the valuation allowance
	for the Company&#146;s deferred tax assets and other tax adjustments. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, after considering all available evidence, both positive (including recent and historical profits, projected future profitability,
	backlog, carryforward periods for, and utilization of net operating loss carryovers and tax credits, discretionary deductions and other factors) and negative (including cumulative losses in past years and other factors), it was concluded that the
	valuation allowance against the Company&#146;s deferred tax assets should be decreased by $0.1&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; less than $0.1&nbsp;million increase). The remaining $0.2&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $0.3 million) balance in the valuation
	allowance as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 is primarily attributable to certain U.S. state net operating loss carryovers that may expire unutilized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(g) Uncertain tax positions
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recorded a net decrease of $1.6&nbsp;million related to the measurement of potential international withholding tax requirements
	and a decrease in reserves for income taxes. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company had total unrecognized tax benefits (including interest and penalties) of $12.6&nbsp;million and $14.6&nbsp;million, respectively, for
	deductibility of stock based compensation, international withholding taxes and other items. Approximately $12.6&nbsp;million of the unrecognized tax benefits could impact the Company&#146;s effective tax rate if recognized. While the Company
	believes it has adequately provided for all tax positions, amounts asserted by taxing authorities could differ from the Company&#146;s accrued position. Accordingly, additional provisions on federal, provincial, state and foreign
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-related
</FONT>
	matters could be recorded in the future as revised estimates are made or the underlying matters are settled or otherwise resolved.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	A reconciliation of the beginning and ending amount of unrecognized tax benefits (excluding interest and penalties) for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31 is as follows:
</P>

	108
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage109"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Consistent with its historical financial reporting, the Company has elected to classify interest
	and penalties related to income tax liabilities, when applicable, as part of the interest expense in its consolidated statements of operations rather than income tax expense. The Company recovered less than $0.1&nbsp;million in potential interest
	and penalties associated with its provision for uncertain tax positions for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 (2015 &#151; less than $0.1&nbsp;million recovery, 2014 &#151; $0.2&nbsp;million recovery).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The number of years with open tax audits varies depending on the tax jurisdiction. The Company&#146;s major taxing jurisdictions include
	Canada, the province of Ontario, the United States (including multiple states), Ireland and China.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s 2011 through 2016
	tax years remain subject to examination by the IRS for U.S. federal tax purposes, and the 2006 through 2016 tax years remain subject to examination by the appropriate governmental agencies for Canadian federal tax purposes. There are other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-going
</FONT>
	audits in various other jurisdictions that are not material to the financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(h)
	Income Tax Effect on Comprehensive Income
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The income tax (expense) benefit related to the following items included in other comprehensive
	income (loss) are:
</P>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other intangible assets of $15.4&nbsp;million are comprised mainly of the Company&#146;s investment in a new
	enterprise resource planning system. Fully amortized other intangible assets are still in use by the Company. In 2016, the Company identified and wrote off $0.2&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $0.1 million) of patents and trademarks that are no longer in
	use.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, the Company acquired $4.8&nbsp;million in other intangible assets. The net book value of these other intangible assets
	was $4.3&nbsp;million as at December&nbsp;31, 2016. The weighted average amortization period for these additions is 10 years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During
	2016, the Company incurred costs of $0.2&nbsp;million to renew or extend the term of acquired patents and trademarks which were recorded in selling, general and administrative expenses (2015 &#151; less than $0.1 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The estimated amortization expense for each of the years ended December&nbsp;31, are as follows:
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	11.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Credit Facility and Playa Vista Loan
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company maintains a senior secured credit
	facility (the &#147;Credit Facility&#148;) with a maximum borrowing capacity of $200.0&nbsp;million and a scheduled maturity of March&nbsp;3, 2020. The Credit Facility is collateralized by a first priority security interest in substantially all of
	the present and future assets of the Company and the Guarantors. Certain of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries serve as guarantors (the &#147;Guarantors&#148;) of the Company&#146;s obligations under the Credit Facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The terms of the Credit Facility are set forth in the Fourth Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (as amended, the &#147;Credit
	Agreement&#148;), dated March&nbsp;3, 2015, among the Company, the Guarantors, the lenders named therein, Wells Fargo Bank, National Association (&#147;Wells Fargo&#148;), as agent and issuing lender (Wells Fargo, together with the lenders named
	therein, the &#147;Lenders&#148;) and Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, as Sole Lead Arranger and Sole Bookrunner and in various collateral and security documents entered into by the Company and the Guarantors. Each of the Guarantors has also entered
	into a guarantee in respect of the Company&#146;s obligations under the Credit Facility. On February&nbsp;22, 2016, the Company amended the terms of the Credit Agreement to increase the general restricted payment basket thereunder (which covers,
	among other things, the repurchase of shares) from $150.0&nbsp;million to $350.0&nbsp;million in the aggregate after the amendment date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company was in compliance with all of its requirements at December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total amounts drawn and available under the Credit Facility at December&nbsp;31, 2016 were $nil and $200.0&nbsp;million, respectively
	(December 31, 2015 &#151; $nil and $200.0&nbsp;million, respectively).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company did not have any letters
	of credit and advance payment guarantees outstanding (December 31, 2015 &#151; $nil), under the Credit Facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Playa Vista Financing
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;6, 2014, IMAX PV Development Inc., a Delaware corporation (&#147;PV Borrower&#148;) and wholly-owned subsidiary of the
	Company, entered into a construction loan agreement with Wells Fargo. The construction loan (the &#147;Playa Vista Construction Loan&#148;) was used to fund $22.3&nbsp;million of the costs of development and construction of the West Coast
	headquarters of the Company, located in the Playa Vista neighborhood of Los Angeles, California (the &#147;Playa Vista Project&#148;).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	October&nbsp;19, 2015, PV Borrower converted the Playa Vista Construction Loan from a construction loan into a permanent loan (&#147;Playa Vista Loan&#148;) pursuant to the terms of the loan documents. Pursuant to the conversion, PV Borrower
	increased the principal balance of the loan by an additional $7.7&nbsp;million, to $30.0&nbsp;million. Prior to the conversion, the Playa Vista Construction Loan bore interest at a variable interest rate per annum equal to 2.25% above the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	30-day
</FONT>
	LIBOR rate, and PV Borrower was required to make monthly payments of interest only. As a result of the conversion, the interest rate decreased from 2.25% to 2.0% above the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	30-day
</FONT>
	LIBOR rate, and PV Borrower will be required to make monthly payments of combined principal and interest over a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-year
</FONT>
	term with a lump sum payment at the end of
	year 10. The Playa Vista Loan is being amortized over 15 years. The Playa Vista Loan will be fully due and payable on October&nbsp;19, 2025 (the &#147;Maturity Date&#148;), and may be prepaid at any time without premium, but with all accrued
	interest and other applicable payments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Playa Vista Loan is secured by a deed of trust from PV Borrower in favor of Wells Fargo and
	other documents evidencing and securing the loan (the &#147;Loan Documents&#148;), granting a first lien on and security interest in the Playa Vista property and the Playa Vista Project, including all improvements to be constructed thereon. The Loan
	Documents include absolute and unconditional payment and completion guarantees provided by the Company to Wells Fargo for the performance by PV Borrower of all the terms and provisions of the Playa Vista Loan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Loan Documents contain affirmative, negative and financial covenants (including compliance with the financial covenants of the
	Company&#146;s outstanding Credit Facility), agreements, representations, warranties, borrowing conditions, and events of default customary for development projects such as the Playa Vista Project.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	111
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Wells Fargo Foreign Exchange Facility
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Within the Credit Facility, the Company is able to purchase foreign currency forward contracts and/or other swap arrangements. The settlement
	risk on its foreign currency forward contracts was $0.3&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 as the notional value exceeded the fair value of the forward contracts. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company has $37.8&nbsp;million in notional value
	of such arrangements outstanding.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Bank of Montreal Facility
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company has available a $10.0&nbsp;million facility (December 31, 2015&nbsp;&#151; $10.0&nbsp;million) with
	the Bank of Montreal for use solely in conjunction with the issuance of performance guarantees and letters of credit fully insured by Export Development Canada (the &#147;Bank of Montreal Facility&#148;). As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company
	has letters of credit and advance payment guarantees outstanding of $0.1&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $0.3 million) under the Bank of Montreal Facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

	The Company&#146;s lease commitments consist of rent and equipment under operating leases. The Company accounts for any incentives provided
	over the term of the lease. The following table summarizes information about the Company&#146;s total rental expenses under operating leases:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Recorded in the accrued liabilities balance as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 is $1.6&nbsp;million (December 31,
	2015&nbsp;&#151; $1.1&nbsp;million) related to accrued rent and lease inducements being recognized as an offset to rent expense over the term of the respective leases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Subsequent to December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company entered into a premises lease arrangement, related to the New York corporate office, with a
	commitment of approximately $17.1&nbsp;million over a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	12-year
</FONT>
	term. The term is expected to begin in January 2018.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Purchase Obligations
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Purchase obligations primarily consist of the Company&#146;s commitments made under long-term supplier contracts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Pension and Postretirement Benefits Obligations
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has an unfunded defined benefit pension plan, covering certain individuals and a postretirement plan to provide health and welfare
	benefits to Canadian employees meeting certain eligibility requirements. See note 20 for further information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Playa Vista Loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is required to make monthly payments of combined principal and interest over a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-year
</FONT>
	term with a lump sum payment at the end of year 10. The Playa Vista Loan will be fully due and payable on October&nbsp;19, 2025. See note 11 for further information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other Financial Commitments
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other financial commitments include the Company&#146;s total minimum commitment toward the development, production, post-production and
	marketing, related to certain film and new content initiatives.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">

<A NAME="eolPage114"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2016 the Company did not have any letters of credit and advance payment
	guarantees outstanding (December 31, 2015&nbsp;&#151; $nil), under the Credit Facility. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016 the Company had letters of credit and advance payment guarantees outstanding of $0.1&nbsp;million as compared to $0.3&nbsp;million
	as at December&nbsp;31, 2015, under the Bank of Montreal Facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company compensates its sales force with both fixed and variable
	compensation. Commissions on the sale or lease of the Company&#146;s theater systems are payable in graduated amounts from the time of collection of the customer&#146;s first payment to the Company up to the collection of the customer&#146;s last
	initial payment. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, $2.0&nbsp;million (December 31, 2015 &#151;$1.7&nbsp;million) of commissions have been accrued and will be payable in future periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	13.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Contingencies and Guarantees
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is involved in lawsuits, claims, and
	proceedings, including those identified below, which arise in the ordinary course of business. In accordance with the Contingencies Topic of the FASB ASC, the Company will make a provision for a liability when it is both probable that a loss has
	been incurred and the amount of the loss can be reasonably estimated. The Company believes it has adequate provisions for any such matters. The Company reviews these provisions in conjunction with any related provisions on assets related to the
	claims at least quarterly and adjusts these provisions to reflect the impacts of negotiations, settlements, rulings, advice of legal counsel and other pertinent information related to the case. Should developments in any of these matters outlined
	below cause a change in the Company&#146;s determination as to an unfavorable outcome and result in the need to recognize a material provision, or, should any of these matters result in a final adverse judgment or be settled for significant amounts,
	they could have a material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s results of operations, cash flows, and financial position in the period or periods in which such a change in determination, settlement or judgment occurs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company expenses legal costs relating to its lawsuits, claims and proceedings as incurred.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(a) On May&nbsp;15, 2006, the Company initiated arbitration against Three-Dimensional Media Group, Ltd. (&#147;3DMG&#148;) before the
	International Centre for Dispute Resolution in New York (the &#147;ICDR&#148;), alleging breaches of the license and consulting agreements between the Company and 3DMG. On June&nbsp;15, 2006, 3DMG filed an answer denying any breaches and asserting
	counterclaims that the Company breached the parties&#146; license agreement. On June&nbsp;21, 2007, the ICDR unanimously denied 3DMG&#146;s Motion for Summary Judgment filed on April&nbsp;11, 2007 concerning the Company&#146;s claims and 3DMG&#146;s
	counterclaims. The proceeding was suspended on May&nbsp;4, 2009 due to failure of 3DMG to pay fees associated with the proceeding. The proceeding was further suspended on October&nbsp;11, 2010 pending resolution of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-examination
</FONT>
	proceedings involving one of 3DMG&#146;s patents. Following a status conference on April&nbsp;27, 2016 before the ICDR, the ICDR granted 3DMG leave to amend its answer and counterclaims, and
	subsequently lifted the stay in this matter. In its amended counterclaims, 3DMG seeks damages for alleged unpaid royalties and other fees under the license and consulting agreements. Discovery is currently ongoing and a final hearing before the ICDR
	has been scheduled for the week of July&nbsp;10, 2017. Given the stage of discovery, the Company is unable to determine a range of potential damages in this matter. However, the Company believes that the amount of loss, if any, suffered in
	connection with the amended counterclaims would not have a material impact on the financial position or results of operations of the Company, although no assurance can be given with respect to the ultimate outcome of the arbitration.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(b) In January 2004, the Company and IMAX Theatre Services Ltd., a subsidiary of the Company, commenced an arbitration seeking damages before
	the International Court of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce (the &#147;ICC&#148;) with respect to the breach by Electronic Media Limited (&#147;EML&#148;) of its December 2000 agreement with the Company. In June 2004, the Company
	commenced a related arbitration before the ICC against EML&#146;s affiliate,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	E-City
</FONT>
	Entertainment (I)&nbsp;PVT Limited
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(&#147;E-City&#148;).
</FONT>
	On March&nbsp;27, 2008, the
	arbitration panel issued a final award in favor of the Company in the amount of $11.3&nbsp;million, consisting of past and future rents owed to the Company, plus interest and costs, as well as an additional $2,512 each day in interest from
	October&nbsp;1, 2007 until the date the award is paid. In July 2008,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	E-City
</FONT>
	commenced a proceeding in Mumbai, India seeking an order that the ICC award may not be recognized in India. The Company has opposed
	that application on a number of grounds and seeks to have the ICC award recognized in India. On June&nbsp;13, 2013, the Bombay High Court ruled that it has jurisdiction over the proceeding but on November&nbsp;19, 2013, the Supreme Court of India
	stayed proceedings in the High Court pending Supreme Court review of the High Court&#146;s ruling. On June&nbsp;24, 2011, the Company commenced a proceeding in the Ontario Superior Court of Justice for recognition of the ICC final award. On
	December&nbsp;2, 2011, the Ontario Court issued an order recognizing the final award and requiring
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	E-City
</FONT>
	to pay the Company $30,000 to cover the costs of the application. In January 2013, the Company filed an
	action in the New York Supreme Court seeking to collect the amount owed to the Company by certain entities and individuals affiliated with
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	E-City.
</FONT>
	On October&nbsp;16, 2015, the New York Supreme Court denied
	the Company&#146;s petition, and the Company is appealing that decision. On July&nbsp;29, 2014, the Company commenced a separate proceeding to have the Canadian judgment against
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	E-City
</FONT>
	recognized in New York,
	and on October&nbsp;2, 2015, the New York Supreme Court granted IMAX&#146;s request, recognizing the Canadian judgment and entering it as a New York judgment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	114
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage115"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;26, 2014,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	E-City
</FONT>
	filed a motion in the Bombay High Court seeking to enjoin IMAX from continuing the New York legal proceedings. On
	February&nbsp;2, 2015, the Bombay High Court denied
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	E-City&#146;s
</FONT>
	request for an injunction. On March&nbsp;16, 2015,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	E-City
</FONT>
	filed an appeal of this Bombay High Court
	decision.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(c) In March 2013, IMAX (Shanghai) Multimedia Technology Co., Ltd. (&#147;IMAX Shanghai&#148;), the Company&#146;s
	majority-owned subsidiary in China, received notice from the Shanghai office of the General Administration of Customs (&#147;Customs Authority&#148;) that it had been selected for a customs audit (the &#147;Audit&#148;). A key issue raised by the
	Audit is the transfer pricing policy basis for the importation of IMAX theater systems by IMAX Shanghai into the People&#146;s Republic of China and the applicability of customs duties and taxes to the trademark and technology license fees paid by
	IMAX Shanghai to the Company. In December 2016, the Customs Authority conclusively determined that any trademark, technology and warranty fees paid by IMAX Shanghai on systems revenue directly related to imported theater systems should be included
	as part of the tax cost base of these systems and subject to applicable duties and taxes. In connection with the conclusion, for the period beginning January 1, 2012 through October&nbsp;31, 2016, IMAX Shanghai recorded $2.95 million in duties and
	taxes on the trademark, technology and warranty fees for applicable to theater systems imported during that period and settled the payment in January 2017. In the course of the Audit, the Customs Authority discovered the underpayment by IMAX
	Shanghai of the freight and insurance portion of the customs duties and taxes applicable to the importation of certain IMAX theater systems during the period from October 2011 through March 2013 of approximately $0.1 million. Though IMAX
	Shanghai&#146;s importation agent accepted responsibility for the error giving rise to the underpayment, the matter has been transferred to the Anti-Smuggling Bureau of the Customs Authority for further review. IMAX Shanghai is unable to assess the
	potential impact, if any, of this outstanding matter at this time.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(d) On November&nbsp;11, 2013, Giencourt Investments, S.A.
	(&#147;Giencourt&#148;) initiated arbitration before the International Centre for Dispute Resolution in Miami, Florida, based on alleged breaches by the Company of its theater agreement and related license agreement with Giencourt. Giencourt
	submitted its statement of claim in January 2015, the Company submitted its statement of defense and counterclaim in April 2015 and Giencourt submitted its arbitration reply paper in September 2015. An arbitration hearing for witness testimony was
	held during the week of December&nbsp;14, 2015. At the hearing, Giencourt&#146;s expert identified monetary damages of up to approximately $10.4&nbsp;million, which Giencourt seeks to recover from the Company. The Company has asserted a counterclaim
	against Giencourt for breach of contract and seeks to recover lost profits in excess of $24.0&nbsp;million under the agreements. In addition, on December&nbsp;10, 2015, Giencourt made a motion to the panel seeking to enforce a purported settlement
	of the matter based on negotiations between Giencourt and the Company. The panel held a final hearing with closing arguments on October 20 and 21, 2016. On February 7, 2017, the panel issued a Partial Final Award (the &#147;Award&#148;), which held
	that the parties had reached a binding settlement, and therefore the panel did not reach the merits of the dispute. The Company strongly disputes that discussions about a potential resolution of this matter amounted to an enforceable settlement. The
	Company is currently reviewing the Award and assessing its response and potential next steps, including a potential challenge in Florida court on the grounds that the panel exceeded its jurisdiction. At this time, the Company is unable to determine
	the amounts that it may owe pursuant to the Award, or the timing of any such payments, and therefore no assurances can be given with respect to the ultimate outcome of the matter.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(e) In addition to the matters described above, the Company is currently involved in other legal proceedings or governmental inquiries which,
	in the opinion of the Company&#146;s management, will not materially affect the Company&#146;s financial position or future operating results, although no assurance can be given with respect to the ultimate outcome of any such proceedings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(f) In the normal course of business, the Company enters into agreements that may contain features that meet the definition of a guarantee.
	The Guarantees Topic of the FASB ASC defines a guarantee to be a contract (including an indemnity) that contingently requires the Company to make payments (either in cash, financial instruments, other assets, shares of its stock or provision of
	services) to a third party based on (a)&nbsp;changes in an underlying interest rate, foreign exchange rate, equity or commodity instrument, index or other variable, that is related to an asset, a liability or an equity security of the counterparty,
	(b)&nbsp;failure of another party to perform under an obligating agreement or (c)&nbsp;failure of another third party to pay its indebtedness when due.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Financial Guarantees
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has provided no significant financial guarantees to third parties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	115
</P>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_50"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Product Warranties
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following summarizes the accrual for product warranties that was recorded as part of accrued liabilities in the consolidated balance
	sheets:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Director/Officer Indemnifications
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s General
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	By-law
</FONT>
	contains an indemnification of its directors/officers, former
	directors/officers and persons who have acted at its request to be a director/officer of an entity in which the Company is a shareholder or creditor, to indemnify them, to the extent permitted by the Canada Business Corporations Act, against
	expenses (including legal fees), judgments, fines and any amount actually and reasonably incurred by them in connection with any action, suit or proceeding in which the directors and/or officers are sued as a result of their service, if they acted
	honestly and in good faith with a view to the best interests of the Company. The nature of the indemnification prevents the Company from making a reasonable estimate of the maximum potential amount it could be required to pay to counterparties. The
	Company has purchased directors&#146; and officers&#146; liability insurance. No amount has been accrued in the consolidated balance sheet as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015 with respect to this indemnity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Other Indemnification Agreements
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the normal course of the Company&#146;s operations, the Company provides indemnifications to counterparties in transactions such as: theater
	system lease and sale agreements and the supervision of installation or servicing of the theater systems; film production, exhibition and distribution agreements; real property lease agreements; and employment agreements. These indemnification
	agreements require the Company to compensate the counterparties for costs incurred as a result of litigation claims that may be suffered by the counterparty as a consequence of the transaction or the Company&#146;s breach or
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performance
</FONT>
	under these agreements. While the terms of these indemnification agreements vary based upon the contract, they normally extend for the life of the agreements. A small number of agreements do not
	provide for any limit on the maximum potential amount of indemnification; however, virtually all of the Company&#146;s system lease and sale agreements limit such maximum potential liability to the purchase price of the system. The fact that the
	maximum potential amount of indemnification required by the Company is not specified in some cases prevents the Company from making a reasonable estimate of the maximum potential amount it could be required to pay to counterparties. Historically,
	the Company has not made any significant payments under such indemnifications and no amounts have been accrued in the consolidated financial statements with respect to the contingent aspect of these indemnities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	116
</P>

<B>

</B>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(a)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Authorized
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Common Shares
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The authorized capital of the Company consists of an unlimited number of common shares. The following is a summary of the rights, privileges,
	restrictions and conditions of the common shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The holders of common shares are entitled to receive dividends if, as and when declared
	by the directors of the Company, subject to the rights of the holders of any other class of shares of the Company entitled to receive dividends in priority to the common shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The holders of the common shares are entitled to one vote for each common share held at all meetings of the shareholders.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(b)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Changes during the Year
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, the Company settled 518,018 (2015 &#151;
	1,761,675, 2014 &#151; 1,149,587) common shares pursuant to the exercise of stock options for cash proceeds of $11.4&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $35.6&nbsp;million, 2014 &#151; $10.8 million). 347,814 (2015 &#151; 1,659,643, 2014 &#151; 1,149,587)
	common shares were newly issued from treasury and 170,204 (2015 &#151; 102,032, 2014 &#151; nil) common shares were purchased in the open market by the IMAX Long-Term Incentive Plan trustee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, during 2016, in connection with the vesting of RSUs, the Company settled 466,918 (2015 &#151; 207,371, 2014 &#151; 148,001)
	common shares to IMAX LTIP participants, of which 54,159 (2015 &#150; 25,551, 2014 &#150; 109,264) common shares, net of shares withheld for tax withholdings of 18,336 (2015 &#150; 14,351, 2014 &#150; 10,921) were issued as new shares from treasury,
	and 394,423 (2015 &#151; 167,469, 2014 &#151; 27,816) common shares were purchased in the open market by the IMAX Long-Term Incentive Plan trustee.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(c)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Stock-Based Compensation
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company issues stock-based compensation to eligible
	employees, directors and consultants under the IMAX Corporation Amended and Restated Long- Term Incentive Plan and the China Long-Term Incentive Plan, as described below.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;11, 2013, the Company&#146;s shareholders approved the IMAX 2013 Long-Term Incentive Plan (the &#147;2013 IMAX LTIP&#148;). On
	June&nbsp;6, 2016, the Company&#146;s shareholders approved the amendment and restatement of the 2013 IMAX LTIP at the Company&#146;s Annual and Special Meeting, such that the IMAX Corporation Amended and Restated Long-Term Incentive Plan (the
	&#147;IMAX LTIP&#148;) is now the governing document, Awards to employees, directors and consultants under the IMAX LTIP may consist of stock options, RSUs and other awards.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s Stock Option Plan (&#147;SOP&#148;), which shareholders approved in June 2008, permitted the grant of stock options to
	employees, directors and consultants. Following the implementation of the 2013 IMAX LTIP on June&nbsp;11, 2013, stock options are no longer granted under the SOP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	A separate stock option plan, the China Long-Term Incentive Plan (the &#147;China LTIP&#148;) was adopted by a subsidiary of the Company in
	October 2012.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The compensation costs recorded in the consolidated statement of operations for these plans were $30.5&nbsp;million in 2016
	(2015&nbsp;&#151; $21.9&nbsp;million, 2014&nbsp;&#151; $15.1 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company has reserved a total of
	12,012,572 (December 31, 2015 &#151; 7,023,258) common shares for future issuance under the SOP and IMAX LTIP. Of the common shares reserved for issuance, there are options in respect of 5,190,542 common shares and RSUs in respect of 1,124,180
	common shares outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2016. At December&nbsp;31, 2016 options in respect of 4,001,078 common shares were vested and exercisable.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	117
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage118"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Stock Option Plan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s policy is to issue new common shares from treasury or shares purchased in the open market to satisfy stock options which are
	exercised.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company utilizes a Binomial Model to determine the fair value of stock-based payment awards. The fair value determined by
	the Binomial Model is affected by the Company&#146;s stock price as well as assumptions regarding a number of highly complex and subjective variables. These variables include, but are not limited to, the Company&#146;s expected stock price
	volatility over the term of the awards, and employee stock option exercise behaviors. The Binomial Model also considers the expected exercise multiple which is the multiple of exercise price to grant price at which exercises are expected to occur on
	average. Option-pricing models were developed for use in estimating the value of traded options that have no vesting or hedging restrictions and are fully transferable. Because the Company&#146;s employee stock options have certain characteristics
	that are significantly different from traded options, and because changes in the subjective assumptions can materially affect the estimated value, in management&#146;s opinion, the Binomial Model best provides a fair measure of the fair value of the
	Company&#146;s employee stock options.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	All awards of stock options are made at fair market value of the Company&#146;s common shares on
	the date of grant. The fair market value of a common share on a given date means the higher of the closing price of a common share on the grant date (or the most recent trading date if the grant date is not a trading date) on the New York Stock
	Exchange (&#147;NYSE&#148;) or such national exchange as may be designated by the Company&#146;s Board of Directors (the &#147;Fair Market Value&#148;). The stock options vest within 5&nbsp;years and expire 10&nbsp;years or less from the date
	granted. The SOP and IMAX LTIP provide for double-trigger accelerated vesting in the event of a change in control, as defined in each plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recorded an expense of $12.8&nbsp;million in 2016 (2015&nbsp;&#151; $10.7&nbsp;million, 2014 &#151; $8.9&nbsp;million) related to
	stock option grants issued to employees and directors in the IMAX LTIP and SOP plans. An income tax benefit is recorded in the consolidated statement of operations of $3.8&nbsp;million for these costs. Total stock-based compensation expense related
	to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-vested
</FONT>
	employee stock options not yet recognized at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and the weighted average period over which the awards are expected to be recognized is $5.9&nbsp;million and 2.3 years
	respectively (2015&nbsp;&#151; $12.6&nbsp;million and 1.7 years, 2014 &#151; $14.8&nbsp;million and 2.3 years).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The weighted average fair
	value of all stock options granted to employees and directors in 2016 at the measurement date was $8.16&nbsp;per share (2015&nbsp;&#151; $8.07 per share, 2014 &#151; $8.25 per share). For the years ended December&nbsp;31, the following assumptions
	were used to estimate the average fair value of the stock options:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Stock options to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-Employees
</FONT>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	There were no common share options issued to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employees
</FONT>
	in 2016 or 2015. During 2014, an aggregate
	of 10,000 stock options to purchase the Company&#146;s common stock with an average exercise price of $26.47 were granted to certain advisors and strategic partners of the Company. These stock options granted have a maximum contractual life of 7
	years. The stock options granted in 2014 were granted under the IMAX LTIP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2016
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employee
</FONT>
	options outstanding amounted to 17,000 stock options (2015&nbsp;&#151; 38,750, 2014&nbsp;&#151; 31,500) with a weighted average exercise price of $29.64 (2015&nbsp;&#151; $26.79, 2014&nbsp;&#151;
	$21.75). 15,200 stock options (2015&nbsp;&#151; 21,525, 2014&nbsp;&#151; 16,100) were exercisable with an average weighted exercise price of $30.10 (2015&nbsp;&#151; $26.34, 2014&nbsp;&#151; $18.14) and the vested options have an aggregate intrinsic
	value of $0.1&nbsp;million (2015&nbsp;&#151; $0.2&nbsp;million, 2014&nbsp;&#151; $0.2 million). The weighted average fair value of stock options granted to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employees
</FONT>
	during 2014 at the measurement date was
	$4.84 per share, utilizing a Binomial Model with the following underlying assumptions:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, the Company recorded a charge of less than $0.1&nbsp;million, (2015&nbsp;&#151; $0.1&nbsp;million,
	2014&nbsp;&#151; $0.1&nbsp;million) to selling, general and administrative expenses related to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employee
</FONT>
	stock options. Included in accrued liabilities is an accrual of less than $0.1&nbsp;million for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employee
</FONT>
	stock options (December 31, 2015 &#151; less than $0.1 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	China Long-Term
	Incentive Plan (&#147;China LTIP&#148;)
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The China LTIP was adopted by IMAX China Holding, Inc. (&#147;IMAX China&#148;), a subsidiary
	of the Company, in October 2012. Each stock option (&#147;China Option&#148;), RSU or cash settled share-based payment (&#147;CSSBP&#148;) issued under the China LTIP represents an opportunity to participate economically in the future growth and
	value creation of IMAX China. Prior to the initial public offering of IMAX China on October&nbsp;8, 2015 (the &#147;IMAX China IPO&#148;), the China Options and CSSBPs issued by IMAX China operated in tandem with options granted to certain employees
	of IMAX China under the Company&#146;s SOP and the IMAX LTIP (&#147;Tandem Options&#148;).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, no Tandem Options were granted in
	conjunction with China Options or CSSBPs. Immediately prior to the IMAX China IPO, there were 186,446 outstanding and unvested Tandem Options issued under the Company&#146;s SOP and IMAX LTIP with a weighted average exercise price of $23.70 per
	share. The Tandem Options had a maximum contractual life of 7 years. The total fair value of the Tandem Options granted with respect to the China LTIP was $1.9&nbsp;million. The Company was recognizing this expense over a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-year
</FONT>
	period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to their terms, upon the occurrence of a qualified initial public offering, the
	186,446 Tandem Options issued would forfeit immediately and the related charge would be reversed. As a result of the IMAX China IPO on October&nbsp;8, 2015, the 186,446 Tandem Options with an average price of $23.70 per share were forfeited
	immediately. The Company recorded a recovery of $0.6&nbsp;million in 2015 (2014 - $0.3&nbsp;million expense) related to the forfeiture of Tandem Options issued under the Company&#146;s SOP and IMAX LTIP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company subsequently recognized an immediate charge related to the vesting of China Options and certain CSSBPs for China employees. The
	total fair value of the China Options and CSSBP awards granted with respect to the China LTIP was $3.9&nbsp;million and $2.1&nbsp;million, respectively. During the fourth quarter of 2015, a charge of $2.1&nbsp;million and $1.4&nbsp;million was
	recorded relating to the China Options and CSSBPs, respectively. The remaining charge will be recognized over the related requisite period. The CSSBPs represent the right to receive cash payments in an amount equal to a certain percentage of the
	excess of the total equity value of IMAX China based on the per share price in the IMAX China IPO over the strike price of the CSSBPs. The CSSBPs were issued in conjunction with the China LTIP, with similar terms and conditions as the China Options.
	The CSSBP awards are accounted as liability awards, however the fair value of the liability is fixed at the time of the initial public offering. During the fourth quarter of 2016, a portion of the CSSBPs vested and were settled in cash for
	$0.5&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $1.0 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with the IMAX China IPO and in accordance with the China LTIP, IMAX China
	adopted a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-IPO
</FONT>
	share option plan and a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-IPO
</FONT>
	restricted stock unit plan. Pursuant to these plans, IMAX China issued additional China Options and China LTIP
	Restricted Share Units (&#147;China RSUs&#148;) during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, the Company recorded an expense
	related to the China Options, China RSUs and CSSBPs of $1.0&nbsp;million, $0.5&nbsp;million and $0.4&nbsp;million, respectively. The liability recognized with respect to the CSSBPs as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $0.3&nbsp;million (December 31,
	2015 &#151; $0.4 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	119
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, the Company cancelled 14,233 stock options from its IMAX LTIP surrendered by Company employees
	(2015&nbsp;&#151; nil, 2014&nbsp;&#151; nil). In 2016 and 2015, the Company did not cancel any stock options from its SOP. In 2014 the Company cancelled 23,787 stock options from its SOP surrendered by Company employees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, 5,190,542 options included both fully vested and unvested options with a weighted average exercise price of
	$28.35, aggregate intrinsic value of $17.6&nbsp;million and weighted average remaining contractual life of 4.3 years. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, options that are exercisable have an intrinsic value of $15.4&nbsp;million and a weighted average
	remaining contractual life of 4.2 years. The intrinsic value of options exercised in 2016 was $5.4&nbsp;million (2015&nbsp;&#151; $29.8&nbsp;million, 2014&nbsp;&#151; $21.8&nbsp;million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the IMAX LTIP trustee held 66,093 shares purchased for $2.0&nbsp;million in the open market to be issued upon
	the settlement of stock options. The shares held with the trustee are recorded at cost and are reported as a reduction against capital stock on the consolidated balance sheet.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Restricted Share Units
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	RSUs have been granted to employees, consultants and directors under the IMAX LTIP. Each RSU represents a contingent right to receive one
	common share and is the economic equivalent of one common share. The grant date fair value of each RSU is equal to the share price of the Company&#146;s stock at the grant date. The Company recorded an expense of $15.8&nbsp;million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 (2015&nbsp;&#151; $8.2&nbsp;million, 2014&nbsp;&#151; $5.8 million), related to RSU grants issued to employees and directors in the plan. The Company did not issue any RSU grants to advisors or strategic partners of the
	Company for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016. The Company recorded an expense of $nil&nbsp;for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 (2015&nbsp;&#151; less than $0.1&nbsp;million, 2014&nbsp;&#151; less than $0.1 million), related to RSU grants
	issued to certain advisors and strategic partners of the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total stock-based compensation expense related to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-vested
</FONT>
	RSUs not yet recognized at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and the weighted average period over which the awards are expected to be recognized is $29.0&nbsp;million and 2.4 years (2015&nbsp;&#151;
	$24.4&nbsp;million and 3.0 years, 2014&nbsp;&#151; $11.0&nbsp;million and 2.9 years). The Company&#146;s actual tax benefits realized for the tax deductions related to the vesting of RSUs was $4.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2016 (2015&nbsp;&#151; $2.0&nbsp;million, 2014&nbsp;&#151; $0.4 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Historically, RSUs granted under the IMAX LTIP have vested
	between immediately and four&nbsp;years from the grant date. In connection with the amendment and restatement of the IMAX LTIP at the Company&#146;s annual and special meeting of shareholders on June&nbsp;6, 2016, the IMAX LTIP plan was amended to
	impose a minimum
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-year
</FONT>
	vesting period on future RSU grants, with a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	carve-out
</FONT>
	for 300,000 RSUs that may vest on a shorter schedule. During 2016, 39,726 RSUs with a
	vesting period of less than one year were issued from the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	carve-out
</FONT>
	of 300,000 RSUs under the amended IMAX LTIP plan. Vesting of the RSUs is subject to continued employment or service with the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	120
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage121"></A>
