<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;16, 2014, the Company&#146;s board of directors approved a new $150.0&nbsp;million share repurchase program for shares of the
	Company&#146;s common stock, which program was amended on April&nbsp;20, 2016 to increase the aggregate purchase allowance to $200.0&nbsp;million. Purchases under the program commenced during the third quarter of 2014, and the program expires on
	June&nbsp;30, 2017.&nbsp;The repurchases may be made either in the open market or through private transactions, subject to market conditions, applicable legal requirements and other relevant factors.&nbsp;The Company has no obligation to repurchase
	shares and the share repurchase program may be suspended or discontinued by the Company at any time.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, the Company repurchased
	3,849,222 (2015 &#151; 1,000,000) common shares at an average price of $30.25 per share (2015 &#151; $34.25 per share). The retired shares were purchased for $116.5&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $34.3 million). The average carrying value of the stock
	retired was deducted from common stock and the remaining excess over the average carrying value of stock was charged to accumulated deficit. Since the inception of the program, the Company has repurchased 4,961,256 common shares at an average price
	of $30.99 per share. The Company has $46.3&nbsp;million available under its approved repurchase program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The total number of shares
	purchased during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 does not include any shares purchased in the administration of employee share-based compensation plans (which amounted to 630,720 (2015 &#150; 269,501) common shares, at an average
	price of $31.52 (2015 &#150; $37.11) per share).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Impact of Stock-based Compensation Accounting Standard Update
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09,
</FONT>
	related to stock-based compensation, was issued in March 2016 and early adopted in June
	2016. ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09
</FONT>
	eliminates the requirement to estimate and apply a forfeiture rate to reduce stock compensation expense during the vesting period and, instead, account for forfeitures as they occur. ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09
</FONT>
	requires that this change be adopted using the modified retrospective approach. The impact from the adoption of the provisions related to forfeiture rates was reflected on a modified retrospective basis
	resulting in a $4.4&nbsp;million decrease to Accumulated earnings, $0.9&nbsp;million increase to Deferred income taxes and $5.3&nbsp;million increase to Other equity. An increase in APIC and a reduction in stock-based compensation expense of
	$2.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was also recorded. Additionally, ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09
</FONT>
	addresses the presentation of excess tax benefits and employee taxes paid on the consolidated statement
	of cash flows. The Company is required to present excess tax benefits as an operating activity on the consolidated statement of cash flows, which is where the Company previously classified these items. ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09
</FONT>
	also requires the presentation of employee taxes as a financing activity on the consolidated statement of cash flows. This change was reflected in the consolidated statement of cash flows
	retrospectively. See notes 3 and 9 for further discussion of the impact from the adoption of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2016-09.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	121
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage122"></A>

	The calculation of diluted earnings per share exclude 2,814,907 (2015 &#151; 1,249,343) shares that are issuable upon exercise
	of 377,048 (2015 &#151; 313,645) RSUs and 2,437,859 (2015 &#151; 935,698) stock options for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, as the impact of these exercises would be antidilutive.

<A NAME="eolPage123"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	15.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Consolidated Statements of Operations Supplemental Information
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(a)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Other Revenues
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company enters into theater system arrangements with
	customers that typically contain customer payment obligations prior to the scheduled installation of the theater systems. During the period of time between signing and theater system installation, certain customers each year are unable to, or elect
	not to, proceed with the theater system installation for a number of reasons, including business considerations, or the inability to obtain certain consents, approvals or financing. Once the determination is made that the customer will not proceed
	with installation, the customer and/or the Company may terminate the arrangement by default or by entering into a consensual buyout. In these situations, the parties are released from their future obligations under the arrangement, and the initial
	payments that the customer previously made to the Company are typically not refunded and are recognized as Other Revenues. In addition, the Company enters into agreements with customers to terminate their obligations for additional theater system
	configurations, which were in the Company&#146;s backlog. Other revenues from settlement arrangements were $1.3&nbsp;million, $0.1&nbsp;million and $nil in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(b)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Foreign Exchange
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included in selling, general and administrative expenses for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 is $0.9&nbsp;million for a net foreign exchange loss related to the translation of foreign currency denominated monetary assets and liabilities as compared to a net loss of $2.4&nbsp;million and a net loss of
	$1.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. See note 19(d) for additional information.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(c)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Collaborative Arrangements
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Joint Revenue Sharing Arrangements
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In a joint revenue sharing arrangement, the Company receives a portion of a theater&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	and concession revenues, and in some cases a small upfront or initial payment, in exchange for placing a theater system at the theater operator&#146;s venue. Under joint revenue sharing arrangements, the customer has the ability and the right to
	operate the hardware components or direct others to operate them in a manner determined by the customer. The Company&#146;s joint revenue sharing arrangements are typically
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cancellable
</FONT>
	for 10 years or
	longer with renewal provisions. Title to equipment under joint revenue sharing arrangements generally does not transfer to the customer. The Company&#146;s joint revenue sharing arrangements do not contain a guarantee of residual value at the end of
	the term. The customer is required to pay for executory costs such as insurance and taxes and is required to pay the Company for maintenance and extended warranty throughout the term. The customer is responsible for obtaining insurance coverage for
	the theater systems commencing on the date specified in the arrangement&#146;s shipping terms and ending on the date the theater systems are delivered back to the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has signed joint revenue sharing agreements with 48&nbsp;exhibitors (2015&nbsp;&#151; 43) for a total of 995&nbsp;theater systems
	(2015&nbsp;&#151; 741), of which 640&nbsp;theaters (2015&nbsp;&#151; 529) were operating as at December&nbsp;31, 2016. The terms of the Company&#146;s joint revenue sharing arrangements are similar in nature, rights and obligations. The accounting
	policy for the Company&#146;s joint revenue sharing arrangements is disclosed in note&nbsp;2(m).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Amounts attributable to transactions
	arising between the Company and its customers under joint revenue sharing arrangements are included in Equipment and Product Sales and Rentals revenue and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 amounted to $91.4&nbsp;million (2015 &#151;
	$99.1&nbsp;million, 2014 &#151; $68.4&nbsp;million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	IMAX DMR
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In an IMAX DMR arrangement, the Company transforms conventional motion pictures into the Company&#146;s large screen format, allowing the
	release of Hollywood content to the global IMAX theater network. In a typical IMAX DMR film arrangement, the Company will absorb its costs for the digital re-mastering and then recoup this cost from a percentage of the box-office receipts of
	the&nbsp;film, which in recent years has averaged approximately 12.5% outside of Greater China and a lower percentage for certain films within Greater China. The Company does not typically hold distribution rights or the copyright to these films.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, the majority of IMAX DMR revenue was earned from the exhibition of 51 IMAX DMR films (2015 &#151; 44) throughout the IMAX
	theater network. The accounting policy for the Company&#146;s IMAX DMR arrangements is disclosed in note 2(m).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	123
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage124"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Amounts attributable to transactions arising between the Company and its customers under IMAX DMR
	arrangements are included in Services revenues and for December&nbsp;31, 2016 amounted to $106.4&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $107.1&nbsp;million, 2014 &#151; $83.2&nbsp;million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Co-Produced
</FONT>
	Film Arrangements
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In certain film arrangements, the Company
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-produces
</FONT>
	a film with a third party whereby the third party
	retains the copyright and rights to the film except that the Company obtains exclusive theatrical distribution rights to the film. Under these arrangements, both parties contribute funding to the Company&#146;s wholly-owned production company for
	the production of the film and for associated exploitation costs. Clauses in the film arrangements generally provide for the third party to take over the production of the film if the cost of the production exceeds its approved budget or if it
	appears as though the film will not be delivered on a timely basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company has one significant
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-produced
</FONT>
	film arrangement which primarily represents the VIE total assets and liabilities balance of $0.4&nbsp;million and five other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-produced
</FONT>
	film arrangements, the
	terms of which are similar. The accounting policies relating to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-produced
</FONT>
	film arrangements are disclosed in notes 2(a) and 2(m).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, amounts totaling $1.4&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $1.5&nbsp;million, 2014 &#151; $3.5&nbsp;million) attributable to transactions
	between the Company and other parties involved in the production of the films have been included in cost and expenses applicable to revenues-services.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	Included in film asset amortization is a charge of $0.2 million (2015&nbsp;&#151;$0.9&nbsp;million, 2014&nbsp;&#151;$0.3 million) relating to changes in estimates based on the ultimate recoverability of future films.

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	In 2016, the Company recorded a charge of $0.5 million&nbsp;(2015 &#151; $0.6&nbsp;million, 2014 &#151; $0.4&nbsp;million, respectively) in costs and expenses applicable to revenues, primarily for its laser-based
	projector inventories. Specifically, IMAX systems includes an inventory charge of $0.2&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $0.5&nbsp;million, 2014 &#151; $0.2 million). Theater system maintenance includes inventory write-downs of $0.2&nbsp;million (2015
	&#151; less than $0.1&nbsp;million, 2014 &#151; $0.2 million).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	In 2016, the Company recorded a charge of $0.3&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $0.4&nbsp;million; 2014 &#151; $0.5 million) reflecting property, plant and equipment that were no longer in use. In 2016, the Company also
	recorded a charge of $0.6&nbsp;million (2015 - $0.6 million) in cost of sales applicable to Equipment and product sales upon the upgrade of xenon-based digital systems under operating lease arrangements to laser-based digital systems under sales or
	sales-type lease arrangements. In addition, in 2015, the Company recorded a charge of $0.5&nbsp;million in cost of sales applicable to Rentals upon the upgrade of certain xenon-based digital systems to laser-based digital systems operating under
	joint revenue sharing arrangements.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

</P>
<A NAME="eolPage127"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	18.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Segmented Information
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has seven reportable segments identified by category
	of product sold or service provided: IMAX systems; theater system maintenance; joint revenue sharing arrangements; film production and IMAX DMR; film distribution; film post-production; and other. The IMAX systems segment includes the design,
	manufacture, sale or lease of IMAX theater projection system equipment. The theater system maintenance segment includes the maintenance of IMAX theater projection system equipment in the IMAX theater network. The joint revenue sharing arrangements
	segment includes the provision of IMAX theater projection system equipment to an exhibitor in exchange for a share of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	and concession revenues. The film production and IMAX DMR segment includes
	the production of films and the performance of film
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastering
</FONT>
	services. The film distribution segment includes the distribution of films for which the Company has distribution rights. The film
	post-production segment provides film post-production and film print services. The Company refers to all theaters using the IMAX theater system as &#147;IMAX theaters&#148;. The other segment includes certain IMAX theaters that the Company owns and
	operates, camera rentals and other miscellaneous items. The accounting policies of the segments are the same as those described in note 2.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Management, including the Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer (&#147;CEO&#148;) who is the Company&#146;s Chief Operating Decision Maker
	(as defined in the Segment Reporting Topic of the FASB ASC), assesses segment performance based on segment revenues, gross margins and film performance. Selling, general and administrative expenses, research and development costs, amortization of
	intangibles, receivables provisions (recoveries), write-downs net of recoveries, interest income, interest expense and tax (provision) recovery are not allocated to the segments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Transactions between the film production and IMAX DMR segment and the film post-production segment are valued at exchange value. Inter-segment
	profits are eliminated upon consolidation, as well as for the disclosures below.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Transactions between the other segments are not
	significant.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Following recent changes in senior management, the Company is in the process of re-evaluating how it assesses the
	performance of the business. As a result of this process, modifications are being made to the CEO&#146;s reporting package to support a revised reporting structure which will move away from the Company&#146;s historic two primary reporting groups
	&#150; IMAX Theater systems and Film. The changes being contemplated will result in four primary reporting groups, comprising (1)&nbsp;Network Business, representing revenue generated by box-office results and which will include the reportable
	segments of DMR and JRSAs excluding hybrid fixed payments; (2)&nbsp;Theater Business, representing revenue generated by the sale and installation of theater systems and maintenance services, primarily related to the IMAX Systems and Theater System
	Maintenance reportable segments, and which will also include fixed hybrid payments from the JRSA segment; (3)&nbsp;New Business, which will include virtual reality, IMAX Shift and IMAX Home Entertainment and (4)&nbsp;Other. The new reporting groups
	are expected to be implemented in the first quarter of 2017. The new reporting structure is expected to assist users of the financial statements with an enhanced understanding of how management views the business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	127
</P>

<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The Company&#146;s largest customer represents 13.5% of total revenues as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 (2015&nbsp;&#150; 16.0%, 2014&nbsp;&#150; 14.5%).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	In 2016, the Company recorded a charge of $0.5&nbsp;million (2015 &#150; $0.6&nbsp;million, 2014&nbsp;&#150; $0.4&nbsp;million, respectively) in costs and expenses applicable to revenues, primarily for its laser-based
	projector inventories. Specifically, IMAX systems includes an inventory charge of $0.2&nbsp;million (2015 &#150; $0.5&nbsp;million, 2014 &#150; $0.2 million). Theater system maintenance includes inventory write-downs of $0.2&nbsp;million (2015
	&#150; less than $0.1&nbsp;million, 2014 &#150; $0.2 million).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	IMAX systems include marketing and commission costs of $3.0&nbsp;million, $3.0&nbsp;million and $2.7&nbsp;million in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Joint revenue sharing arrangements segment margins include
	advertising, marketing, and commission costs of $4.1&nbsp;million, $4.3&nbsp;million and $3.2&nbsp;million in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Production and DMR segment margins include marketing costs of $17.5&nbsp;million, $13.3&nbsp;million and
	$7.1&nbsp;million in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Distribution segment margins include marketing expense of $2.2&nbsp;million, recovery of $0.1&nbsp;million and expense of $0.6&nbsp;million in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Goodwill is allocated on a relative fair market value basis to the IMAX systems segment, theater system maintenance segment and joint revenue sharing segment. There has been no change in the allocation of goodwill from
	the prior year.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	130
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	(b)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Geographic Information
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue by geographic area is based on the
	location of the customer. Revenue related to IMAX DMR is presented based upon the geographic location of the theaters that exhibit the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-mastered
</FONT>
	films. IMAX DMR revenue is generated through contractual
	relationships with studios and other third parties and these may not be in the same geographical location as the theater.
</P>

	No single country in the Rest of the World, Western Europe, Latin America and Asia (excluding Greater China)
	classifications comprise more than 10% of total revenue.

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	19.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Financial Instruments
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	(a)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Financial Instruments
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company maintains cash with various major
	financial institutions. The Company&#146;s cash is invested with highly rated financial institutions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s accounts
	receivables and financing receivables are subject to credit risk. The Company&#146;s accounts receivable and financing receivables are concentrated with the theater exhibition industry and film entertainment industry. To minimize the Company&#146;s
	credit risk, the Company retains title to underlying theater systems leased, performs initial and ongoing credit evaluations of its customers and makes ongoing provisions for its estimate of potentially uncollectible amounts. The Company believes it
	has adequately provided for related exposures surrounding receivables and contractual commitments.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

</B>

	(b)

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The carrying values of the Company&#146;s cash
	and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued liabilities due within one year approximate fair values due to the short-term maturity of these instruments. The Company&#146;s other financial instruments at December&nbsp;31,
	are comprised of the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash and cash equivalents are comprised of cash and interest-bearing investments with original maturity dates
	to the Company of 90 days or less. Cash and cash equivalents are recorded at cost, which approximates fair value (Level 1 input in accordance with the Fair Value Measurements Topic of the FASB ASC hierarchy) as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015,
	respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The estimated fair values of the net financed sales receivable and net investment in sales-type leases are estimated based
	on discounting future cash flows at currently available interest rates with comparable terms (Level&nbsp;2 input in accordance with the Fair Value Measurements Topic of the FASB ASC hierarchy) as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value of the Company&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	available-for-sale
</FONT>
</FONT>
	investment is determined using quoted prices in active markets (Level 2 input in accordance with the Fair Value Measurements Topic of the FASB&nbsp;ASC hierarchy) as at December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value of the Company&#146;s convertible loan receivable approximates market value as at December&nbsp;31, 2016, as the loan was
	recently issued (Level 2 input in accordance with the Fair Value Measurements Topic of the FASB ASC hierarchy).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value of foreign
	currency derivatives are determined using quoted prices in active markets (Level&nbsp;2 input in accordance with the Fair Value Measurements Topic of the FASB ASC hierarchy) as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. These identical
	instruments are traded on a closed exchange.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The carrying value of borrowings under the Playa Vista Loan approximates fair value as the
	interest rates offered under the loan are close to December&nbsp;31, 2016 market rates for the Company for debt of the same remaining maturities (Level&nbsp;2 input in accordance with the Fair Value Measurements Topic of the FASB ASC hierarchy) as
	at December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	There were no significant transfers between Level&nbsp;1 and Level&nbsp;2 during the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 or 2015. When a determination is made to classify an asset or liability within Level&nbsp;3, the determination is based upon the significance of the unobservable inputs to the overall fair value measurement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	132
</P>

<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	There were no transfers in or out of the Company&#146;s Level&nbsp;3 assets during the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	(c)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Financing Receivables
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s net investment in leases and its
	net financed sale receivables are subject to the disclosure requirements of ASC&nbsp;310 &#147;Receivables&#148;. Due to differing risk profiles of its net investment in leases and its net financed sales receivables, the Company views its net
	investment in leases and its net financed sale receivables as separate classes of financing receivables. The Company does not aggregate financing receivables to assess impairment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company monitors the credit quality of each customer on a frequent basis through collections and aging analyses. The Company also holds
	meetings monthly in order to identify credit concerns and whether a change in credit quality classification is required for the customer. A customer may improve in their credit quality classification once a substantial payment is made on overdue
	balances or the customer has agreed to a payment plan with the Company and payments have commenced in accordance to the payment plan. The change in credit quality indicator is dependent upon management approval.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company classifies its customers into four categories to indicate the credit quality worthiness of its financing receivables for internal
	purposes only:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Good standing &#151; Theater continues to be in good standing with the Company as the client&#146;s payments and reporting
	are
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	up-to-date.
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Credit Watch &#151; Theater operator has
	begun to demonstrate a delay in payments, and has been placed on the Company&#146;s credit watch list for continued monitoring, but active communication continues with the Company. Depending on the size of outstanding balance, length of time in
	arrears and other factors, transactions may need to be approved by management. These financing receivables are considered to be in better condition than those receivables related to theaters in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	&#147;Pre-approved
</FONT>
	transactions&#148; category, but not in as good of condition as those receivables in &#147;Good standing.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Pre-approved
</FONT>
	transactions only &#151; Theater operator is demonstrating a delay in payments with
	little or no communication with the Company. All service or shipments to the theater must be reviewed and approved by management. These financing receivables are considered to be in better condition than those receivables related to theaters in the
	&#147;All transactions suspended&#148; category, but not in as good of condition as those receivables in &#147;Credit Watch.&#148; Depending on the individual facts and circumstances of each customer, finance income recognition may be suspended if
	management believes the receivable to be impaired.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	All transactions suspended &#151; Theater is severely delinquent,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-responsive
</FONT>
	or not negotiating in good faith with the Company. Once a theater is classified as &#147;All transactions suspended&#148; the theater is placed on nonaccrual status and all revenue recognitions
	related to the theater are stopped.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	133
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	While recognition of finance income is suspended, payments received by a customer are applied against the
	outstanding balance owed. If payments are sufficient to cover any unreserved receivables, a recovery of provision taken on the billed amount, if applicable, is recorded to the extent of the residual cash received. Once the collectibility issues are
	resolved and the customer has returned to being in good standing, the Company will resume recognition of finance income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	Company&#146;s investment in financing receivables on nonaccrual status is as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company considers financing receivables with aging between
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	60-89
</FONT>
	days as indications of theaters with potential collection concerns. The Company will begin to focus its review on these financing receivables and increase its discussions internally and with the theater regarding payment status. Once a
	theater&#146;s aging exceeds 90 days, the Company&#146;s policy is to review and assess collectibility on the theater&#146;s past due accounts. Over 90 days past due is used by the Company as an indicator of potential impairment as invoices up to 90
	days outstanding could be considered reasonable due to the time required for dispute resolution or for the provision of further information or supporting documentation to the customer.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	134
</P>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company considers financing receivables to be impaired when it believes it to be probable
	that it will not recover the full amount of principal or interest owing under the arrangement. The Company uses its knowledge of the industry and economic trends, as well as its prior experiences to determine the amount recoverable for impaired
	financing receivables. The following table discloses information regarding the Company&#146;s impaired financing receivables:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	(d)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Foreign Exchange Risk Management
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is exposed to market risk
	from changes in foreign currency rates. A majority portion of the Company&#146;s revenues is denominated in U.S. dollars while a substantial portion of its costs and expenses is denominated in Canadian dollars. A portion of the net U.S. dollar cash
	flows of the Company is periodically converted to Canadian dollars to fund Canadian dollar expenses through the spot market. In China and Japan the Company has ongoing operating expenses related to its operations in Chinese Renminbi and Japanese
	yen, respectively. Net cash flows are converted to and from U.S. dollars through the spot market. The Company also has cash receipts under leases denominated in Chinese Renminbi, Japanese yen, Canadian dollars and Euros which are converted to U.S.
	dollars through the spot market. In addition, because IMAX films generate
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	in 74 different countries, unfavourable exchange rates between applicable local currencies, and the U.S. dollar affect the
	Company&#146;s reported gross
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	box-office
</FONT>
	and revenues, further impacting the Company&#146;s results of operations. The Company&#146;s policy is to not use any financial instruments for trading or other
	speculative purposes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company entered into a series of foreign currency forward contracts to manage the Company&#146;s risks
	associated with the volatility of foreign currencies. Certain of these foreign currency forward contracts met the criteria required for hedge accounting under the Derivatives and Hedging Topic of the FASB ASC at inception, and continue to meet hedge
	effectiveness tests at December&nbsp;31,
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	137
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage138"></A>

</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	2016 (the &#147;Foreign Currency Hedges&#148;), with settlement dates throughout 2017 and 2018. Foreign currency derivatives are recognized and measured in the balance sheet at fair value.
	Changes in the fair value (gains or losses) are recognized in the consolidated statement of operations except for derivatives designated and qualifying as foreign currency hedging instruments. For foreign currency hedging instruments, the effective
	portion of the gain or loss in a hedge of a forecasted transaction is reported in other comprehensive income and reclassified to the consolidated statement of operations when the forecasted transaction occurs. Any ineffective portion is recognized
	immediately in the consolidated statement of operations. The Company currently does not hold any derivatives which are not designated as hedging instruments and therefore no gain or loss pertaining to an ineffective portion has been recognized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following tabular disclosures reflect the impact that derivative instruments and hedging activities have on the Company&#146;s
	consolidated financial statements:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Notional value of foreign exchange contracts:
</P>

	The Company&#146;s estimated net amount of the existing gains as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 is
	$0.1&nbsp;million, which is expected to be reclassified to earnings within the next twelve months
</P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="4%">

<B>

<B>
<I>
	(e)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Investments in New Business Ventures
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company accounts for investments
	in new business ventures using the guidance of the FASB ASC&nbsp;323 and the FASB ASC&nbsp;320, as appropriate. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the equity method of accounting is being utilized for investments with a total carrying value of $nil
	(December 31, 2015 &#151; $1.0 million). The Company&#146;s accumulated losses in excess of its equity investment were $0.5 million as at December 31, 2016, and are classified in Accrued and other liabilities. For the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2016, gross revenues, cost of revenue
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	138
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage139"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	and net loss for the investment were $0.6&nbsp;million, $6.8&nbsp;million and $6.2&nbsp;million, respectively (2015 &#151; $nil, $9.3&nbsp;million, and $9.1&nbsp;million, respectively). The
	Company has determined it is not the primary beneficiary of this VIE, and therefore this entity has not been consolidated. In 2016, the Company issued a convertible loan of $1.0&nbsp;million to this entity with a term of 3 years with an annual
	effective interest rate of 5.0%.&nbsp;The instrument is classified as an
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	available-for-sale
</FONT>
</FONT>
	investment due to certain features that allow for conversion to common stock
	in the entity in the event of certain triggers occurring. In addition, the Company has an investment in preferred stock of another business venture of $1.5&nbsp;million which meets the criteria for classification as a debt security under the FASB
	ASC&nbsp;320 and is recorded at a fair value of $nil at December&nbsp;31, 2016 (December 31, 2015&nbsp;&#151; $nil). This investment was classified as an
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	available-for-sale
</FONT>
</FONT>
	investment. Furthermore, the Company has an investment of $1.0&nbsp;million (December 31, 2015&nbsp;&#151; $1.0 million) in the shares of an exchange
	traded fund. This investment is also classified as an
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	available-for-sale
</FONT>
</FONT>
	investment. The Company has an investment of $2.5&nbsp;million in the preferred shares of an
	enterprise which meet the criteria for classification as an equity security under FASB ASC 325. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company recognized an other-than-temporary impairment of $0.2&nbsp;million (2015&nbsp;&#151; $0.4 million) in the
	consolidated statement of operations. The total carrying value of investments in new business ventures at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 is $1.0&nbsp;million and $2.2&nbsp;million, respectively, and is recorded in Other Assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	20.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Employee&#146;s Pension and Postretirement Benefits
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	(a)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Defined Benefit Plan
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has an unfunded U.S.&nbsp;defined
	benefit pension plan, the SERP, covering Richard L. Gelfond, Chief Executive Officer (&#147;CEO&#148;) of the Company. The SERP provides for a lifetime retirement benefit from age&nbsp;55 determined as 75% of Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond&#146;s best average 60
	consecutive months of earnings over his employment history. The benefits were 50% vested as at July 2000, the SERP initiation date. The vesting percentage increased on a straight-line basis from inception until age&nbsp;55. As at December&nbsp;31,
	2016, the benefits of Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond were 100% vested. Upon a termination for cause, prior to a change of control, Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond shall forfeit any and all benefits to which he may have been entitled, whether or not vested.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under the terms of the SERP, if Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond&#146;s employment terminated other than for cause (as defined in his employment agreement),
	he is entitled to receive SERP benefits in the form of a lump sum payment. SERP benefit payments to Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond are subject to a deferral for six months after the termination of his employment, at which time Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond will be entitled to
	receive interest on the deferred amount credited at the applicable federal rate for short-term obligations. Pursuant to an employment agreement dated November&nbsp;8, 2016, the term of Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond&#146;s employment was extended through
	December&nbsp;31, 2019, although Mr.&nbsp;Gelfond has not informed the Company that he intends to retire at that time. Under the terms of the arrangement, no compensation earned beginning in 2011 is included in calculating his entitlement under the
	SERP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following assumptions were used to determine the obligation and cost of the Company&#146;s SERP at the plan measurement dates:
</P>

	&nbsp;

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(b)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Defined Contribution Pension Plan
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company also maintains defined
	contribution pension plans for its employees, including its executive officers. The Company makes contributions to these plans on behalf of employees in an amount up to 5% of their base salary subject to certain prescribed maximums. During 2016, the
	Company contributed and expensed an aggregate of $1.2&nbsp;million (2015 &#151; $1.1&nbsp;million, 2014&nbsp;&#151; $1.4&nbsp;million) to its Canadian plan and an aggregate of $0.6&nbsp;million (2015&nbsp;&#151; $0.4&nbsp;million, 2014&nbsp;&#151;
	$0.4&nbsp;million) to its defined contribution employee pension plan under Section&nbsp;401(k) of the U.S.&nbsp;Internal Revenue Code.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In
	September 2016, the Company entered into a new employment agreement with Greg Foster, CEO of IMAX Entertainment and Senior Executive Vice President of the Company, which provides for an employment term from July&nbsp;2, 2016 through July&nbsp;2,
	2019. Under the agreement, the Company agreed to create a deferred compensation plan (the &#147;Retirement Plan&#148;) covering Mr.&nbsp;Foster, and to make a total contribution of $3.2&nbsp;million over the three-year employment term. The
	Retirement Plan is subject to a vesting schedule based on continued employment with the Company, such that 25% will vest July 2019; 50% will vest July 2022; 75% will vest July 2025; and Mr. Foster will be 100% vested in July 2027. As at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had an unfunded benefit obligation recorded of $0.5&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	140
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage141"></A>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(c)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Postretirement Benefits - Executives
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has an unfunded postretirement
	plan for Messrs. Gelfond and Bradley J. Wechsler, Chairman of the Company&#146;s Board of Directors. The plan provides that the Company will maintain health benefits for Messrs. Gelfond and Wechsler until they become eligible for Medicare and,
	thereafter, the Company will provide Medicare supplemental coverage as selected by Messrs. Gelfond and Wechsler.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The amounts accrued for
	the plan are determined as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has an unfunded
	postretirement plan for its Canadian employees upon meeting specific eligibility requirements. The Company will provide eligible participants, upon retirement, with health and welfare benefits.
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D339843D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Weighted average assumptions used to determine the net postretirement benefit expense are:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="84%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="82%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="4%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="4%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="4%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(a)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	IMAX China
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-Controlling
</FONT>
	Interest
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	April&nbsp;8, 2014, the Company announced sale and issuance of 20% of the shares of IMAX China to entities owned and controlled by CMC Capital Partners (&#147;CMC&#148;), an investment fund that is focused on media and entertainment, and
	FountainVest Partners (&#147;FountainVest&#148;), a China-focused private equity firm. The sale price for the interest was $80.0&nbsp;million, and was paid by the investors in two equal installments on April&nbsp;8, 2014 and February&nbsp;10, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;8, 2015, IMAX China completed the IMAX China IPO. Following the IMAX China IPO, the Company continues to indirectly own
	approximately 68.2% of IMAX China, which remains a consolidated subsidiary of the Company. On October&nbsp;15, 2015, in satisfaction of its obligations under the shareholders&#146; agreement, IMAX China paid a dividend of $9.5&nbsp;million to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest shareholders.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following summarizes the movement of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest in temporary equity, in the Company&#146;s subsidiary for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(b)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-Controlling
</FONT>
	Interest
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2014,
	the Company announced the creation of the Film Fund to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-finance
</FONT>
	a portfolio of 10 original large-format films. The Film Fund, which is intended to be capitalized with up to $50.0&nbsp;million, will finance
	an ongoing supply of original films that the Company believes will be more exciting and compelling than traditional documentaries. The initial investment in the Film Fund was committed to by a third party in the amount of $25.0&nbsp;million, with
	the possibility of contributing additional funds. The Company agreed to contribute $9.0&nbsp;million to the Film Fund over five years starting in 2014 and sees the Film Fund as a self-perpetuating vehicle designed to generate a continuous, steady
	flow of high-quality documentary content. As at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Film Fund invested $13.4&nbsp;million toward the development of original films. The related production, financing and distribution agreement includes put and call rights
	relating to change of control of the rights, title and interest in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-financed
</FONT>
	pictures.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has accrued costs related to obligations in
	respect of required reversion costs for its owned and operated theaters under long-term real estate leases which will become due in the future. The Company does not have any legal restrictions with respect to settling any of these long-term leases.
	A reconciliation of the Company&#146;s liability in respect of required reversion costs is shown below:

<EFX_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES>
<A NAME="FIS_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<A NAME="D339843D10K_HTM_TX339843_15">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;9A.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Controls
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	and
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Procedures
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	EVALUATION OF
	DISCLOSURE CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company maintains disclosure controls and procedures designed to ensure that information
	required to be disclosed in reports filed under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the specified time periods and that such information is accumulated and communicated to
	management, including the CEO and Chief Financial Officer (&#147;CFO&#148;), to allow timely discussions regarding required disclosure. There are inherent limitations to the effectiveness of any system of disclosure controls and procedures,
	including the possibility of human error and the circumvention or overriding of the controls and procedures. Accordingly, even effective disclosure controls and procedures can only provide reasonable assurance of achieving their control objectives.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s management, with the participation of its CEO and its CFO, has evaluated the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s
	&#147;disclosure controls and procedures&#148; (as defined in the Securities Exchange Act of 1934
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Rules&nbsp;13a-15(e)
</FONT>
	or
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	15d-15(e))
</FONT>
	as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and has
	concluded that, as of the end of the period covered by this report, the Company&#146;s disclosure controls and procedures were effective. The Company will continue to periodically evaluate its disclosure controls and procedures and will make
	modifications from time to time as deemed necessary to ensure that information is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC&#146;s rules and forms.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	MANAGEMENT&#146;S ANNUAL REPORT ON INTERNAL CONTROL OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting for the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Management has used the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (&#147;COSO&#148;) framework in Internal
	Control-Integrated Framework (2013)&nbsp;to assess the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Management has assessed the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting, as at December&nbsp;31, 2016, and
	has concluded that such internal control over financial reporting were effective as at that date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Because of its inherent limitations,
	internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions,
	or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP has audited the
	effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting as at December&nbsp;31, 2016 as stated in their report on page 80.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	CHANGES IN INTERNAL CONTROL OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the first quarter of 2016, the Company&#146;s subsidiary, IMAX China Holding, Inc. (&#147;IMAX China&#148;), implemented a new
	enterprise resource planning (&#147;ERP&#148;) system. The implementation of the new ERP system resulted in material changes to the nature and type of IMAX China&#146;s internal controls over financial reporting during the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016. The Company reviewed the implementation effort as well as the impact on its internal controls over financial reporting and where appropriate, has made changes to these controls over financial reporting to address these system
	changes. The Company believes that the internal control changes resulting from the new ERP implementation in China will improve the overall control environment. There were no other changes in the Company&#146;s internal control over financial
	reporting which occurred during the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.
</P>
</EFX_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
